editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by idREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Empresse of Babylon 1 King 2 King 3 King 1 Cardinal; Como 2 Cardinal 3 Cardinal 4 Cardinal Titania Fidely Florimel Elfiron Parthenophill Plain Dealing Paridel; a doctor Prologue Campeius; a scholar Conjurer Lupus Truth Time Palmio; a Jesuit Aura (Maid) Omnes/Amb/Tres/All 3 4 Footmen Ragazzani Gentleman Albonoys Alba. Ropus Com. Herald Coz/Cox/kinsman of doctor Volunteer

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: proLOGVE.
sp.l: The Charms of silence through this Square be thrown,
That an unused Attention (like a Jewel)
May hang at every ear, for we present
Matter above the vulgar Argument:
Yet drawn so lively, that the weakest eye,
(Through those thin veils we hang between your sight,
And this our piece) may reach the mystery:
What in it is most grave, will most delight.
But as in Landscape, Towns and Woods appear
Small afar off, yet to the Optic sense,
The mind shows them as great as those more near;
So, winged Time that long ago flew hence
You must fetch back, with all those golden years
He stole, and here imagine still he stands,
Thrusting his silver lock into your hands.
There hold it but two hours, It shall from Graves
Raise up the dead: upon this narrow floor
Swell up an Ocean, (with an Armed Fleet,)
And lay the Dragon at a Doves soft feet.
These Wonders sit and see, sending as guides
Your Judgment, not your passions: passion slides,
When Judgment goes upright: for though the Muse
( That is thus inspired) a Novel path does tread,
She is free from foolish boldness, or base dread.
Lo; scorn she scorns and Envies rankling tooth,
For this is all she does, she wakens Truth.

stage.p: He draws a Curtain, discovering Truth in sad habiliments; uncrowned: her hair disheveled, and sleeping on a Rock: Time (her father) attired likewise in black and all his properties (as Sith, Hourglass and Wings) of the same Colour, using all means to waken Truth, but not being able to do it, he sits by her and mourns. Then enter Friars, Bishops, Cardinals before the Hearse of a Queen, after it Councillors, Pensioners and Ladies, all these last having scarfs before their eyes, the other singing in Latin. Truth suddenly awakens, and beholding this sight, shows (with her father) arguments of Joy, and Exeunt, returning presently: Time being shifted into light Colours, his properties likewise altered into silver, and Truth Crowned, (being clothed in a robe spotted with Stars) meet the Hearse, and pulling the veils from the Counsellors eyes, they wondering a while, and seeming astonished at her brightness, at length embrace Truth and Time, and depart with them: leaving the rest going on.

This being done, Enter Titania (the Fairy Queen) attended with those Councillors, and other persons fitting her estate: Time and Truth meet her, presenting a Book to her, which (kissing it) she receives, and showing it to those about her, they draw out their swords, (embracing Truth,) vowing to defend her and that book: Truth then and Time are sent in, and return presently, driving before them those Cardinals, Friars etc. (that came in before) with Images, Crosier staves etc. They gon, certain grave learned men, that had been banished, are brought in, and presented to Titania, who shows to them the book, which they receive with great signs of gladness, and Exeunt Omnes.

div1.stage: Empress of Babylon: her Canopy supported by 4. Cardinals: 2. persons in Pontifical robes on either hand, the one bearing a sword, the other the keies: before her 3. Kings crowned, behinde her Friars, etc.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: That we, in pomp, in peace, in god-like splendour,
With adoration of all dazzled eyes,
Should breath thus long, and grow so full of days,
Be fruitful as the Vine, in sons and daughters,
(All Emperors, Kings, and Queens) that (like to Cedars
Uprising from the breast of Lybanus,
Or Olives nursed up by Ierusalem)
Heightened our glories, whilst we held up them:
That this vast Globe Terrestrial should be cantled,
And almost three parts ours, and that the nations,
Who suspiration draw out of this air,
With universal Aves, shouts, and cries,
Should us acknowledge to be head supreme
To this great body (for a world of years:)
Yet now, when we had made our Crown complete,
And closed it strongly with a triple arch,
And had enriched it with those precious jewels
Few Princes ever see (white hairs) even now
Our greatness hangs in balance, and the stamp
Of our true Sovereignty, clipped, and abased.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: By whom dread Empress?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Ask these holy Fathers:
Ask those our out-cast sons: a throne usurped
Our chair is counted, all our titles stolen.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: What blasphemy dare speak so?

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: All our robes,
Your vestments, (reverend, yet pontifical:)
This sword, these keys, (that open kingdoms hearts
To let in sweet obedience) All, but borrowed.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: What soul above the earth --

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Our royal signet,
With which, we, (in a mothers holy love )
Have signed so many pardons, is now counterfeit:
From our mouth flow rivers of blasphemy
And lies; our Babylonian Synagogues
Are counted Stews, where Fornications
And all uncleanness Sodomiticall,
(Whose leprosy touched us never) are now daily acted:
Our Image, which (like Romane Caesars) stamped
In gold, through the whole earth did currant pass;
Is now blanched copper, or but gilded brass.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Can yonder roof, that is nailed so fast with stars,
Cover a head so impious, and not crack?
That Sulphur boiling over celestial fires,
May drop in whizzing flakes (with scalding vengeance)
On such a horrid sin!

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Is so unsanctified.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Who is it bright Empress,
That feeds so ulcerous, and so rank a Spleen?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: A woman.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Woman! who?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The Fairy Queen:
Five Summers have scarce drawn their glimmering nights
Through the Moons silver bow, since the crowned heads
Of that adored beast, on which we ride,
Were struck and wounded, but so healed again,
The very scars were hid. But now, a mortal,
An unrecoverable bloW is taken,
And it must bleed to death.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Heaven cannot suffer it.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Heaven suffers it, and sees it, and gives aim,
Whilst even our Empires heart is cleft in sunder:
That strumpet, that enchantress, (who, in robes
White as is innocence, and with an eye
Able to tempt stern murther to her bed)
Calls herself Truth, has stolen fair Truths attire,
Her crown, her sweet songs, counterfeits her voice,
And by prestigious tricks in sorcery,
Has raised a base impostor like Truths father:
This subtle Courtesan sets up again,
Whom we but late banished, to live in caves,
In rocks and desert mountains.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Fear her not, she is but a shadow.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: O it is a cunning Spider,
And in her nets so wraps the Fairy Queen,
That she sucks even her breast: She has writ a book,
Which she calls holy Spells.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: We will break those spells.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: The poles of heaven must first in sunder break,
For from the Fairy shores this Witch hath driven
All such as are like these (our soothsayers)
And called false Seers home, that of things past,
Sing wonders, and divine of things to come:
Through whose bewitching tongues run golden chains,
To which ten thousand ears so fast are bound,
As spirits are by spells; that all the Tones
Of harmony, that Babylon can sound,
Are charms to Adders, and no more regarded,
Than are by him that is deaf, the sick man's groans
She, they, Titania, and her Fairy Lords,
Yea even her vassal elves, in public scorn
Defame me, call me Whore of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O unheard of profanation!

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: give out I am common: that for lust, and hire
I prostitute this body: that to Kings
I quaff full bowls of strong enchanting wines,
To make them dote on me.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Let us hear no more.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: And that all Potentates that tread on earth,
With our abominations should be drunk,
And be by us undone.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We will hear no more.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You have thrust Furies whips into our hands.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Say but the word, and we will turn home your wrongs,
In torn and bloody colours.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: All her bowers,
Shall like burnt offerings purge away (in fire)
Her lands pollution.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Let us to arms.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Stay: hear me:
Her kingdom wears a girdle wrought of waves,
Set thick with precious stones, that are so charmed,
No rocks are of more force: her Fairies hearts,
Lie in enchanted towers (impregnable)
No engine scales them. Therefore go you three,
Draw all your faces sweetly, let your brows
Be sleeked, your cheeks in dimples, give out smiles,
Your voices string with silver, woo (like lovers)
Swear you have hills of pearl: show her the world,
And say she shall have all, so she will kneel
And do us reverence: but if she grow nice,
Dissemble, flatter, stoop to lick the dust
She goes upon, and (like to serpents) creep
Upon your bellies, in humility;
And beg she would but with us join a league,
To wed her land to ours: our blessing, go.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: When mines are to be blown up, men dig low.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.l: And so will we.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Prosper: till this sun set
The beams that from us shoot, seem counterfeit.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: This physic cures not me.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: Nor me.

sp.speaker: 3. Card.
sp.l: Nor us.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: It is not strong of poison, to fetch up
that is baked within: my gall is overflown,
My blood grown rank and foul: An inflammation
Of rage, and madness so burns up my liver,
That even my heart-strings crack (as in a furnace)
And all my nerves into my eyeballs shrink,
To shoot those bullets, and my brains at once
Against her soul that has half damned us: falls
Fetched hie, and near to heaven, light on no ground,
But in hells bottom, take their first rebound.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: Such are our falls: we once had mountain-growth,
With Pines and Cedars.

sp.speaker: 3. Card.
sp.l: Now with none of both.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: I could be glad to loose the divine office
Of my creation, to be turned into
A dog, so I might lick up but her blood,
That thrusts us from our vineyards.

sp.speaker: Tres.
sp.l: So could all.

sp.speaker: 4. Card.
sp.l: Revenge were milk to us.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: Manna.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: And it shall.
But how? we will not (as the head supreme
Over all nations, counselleth) lick the dust
The Fairy treads on, nor (like serpents) creep
Upon our bellies in humility:
This were (with Fencers) basely to give ground,
When the first bout may speed: or to sound parley,
Whilst they within, get swords to cut our throats:
No, we will at one blow strike the heart through.

sp.speaker: Tres.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: By poniards.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 3. Card.
sp.l: Poison.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 4. Card.
sp.l: Treason.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: How (reverend Como) then?

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Thus -- let us consult -- nay you shall hear.
You know that all the springs in Fairy land
Ran once to one head: from that head, to us:
The mountain and the valley paid us fruit;
The field her corn, the country felt no heat
But from our fires: Plenty still spread our boards,
And Charity took away. We stepped not forth
But with a god like adoration
All knees bowed low unto us: why was this?
Why were our gardens Eden? why our bowers
Built like to those in Paradise? I shall tell you,
It was because the Law most mystical,
Was not made common: therefore was not vile;
It was because in the great Prophets Fanes
And hallowed Temples, we were Choristers:
It was because (wise Pilots) we from rocks,
And gulfs infernal, safely set on shore
Men's souls at yonder haven: or ( being shipwrecked)
Strong lines forth cast we, suffering none to sink
To that Abyss, which some hold bottomless.
But now our very graves
Cannot save dead men's bones from shame and bruises.
The monumental marble Urns of bodies
(Laid to rest long ago) unreverently
Are turned to troughs of water now for jades:
Vast Charnel-houses, where our fathers heads
Slept on the cold hard pillows of the earth,
Are emptied now, and changed to drinking rooms,
Or vaults for baser office.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: What is therefore to be done?

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: This must be done:
This shall be done: They hunted us like wolves,
Out of their Fairy forests, whipped us away
(As vagabonds) mocked us, and said our fall
Could not be dangerous, because we bore
Our gods upon our backs: now must we whip them,
But wiselier.

sp.speaker: Tres.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Thus: those that fill our rooms,
Hold Beacons in their eyes (blazing with fire
Of a hot-seeming zeal) to watch our entrance,
And to arm all against us: these we must quench:
They are counted wells of knowledge, poison these wells:
They are the kingdoms music, they the Organs,
Unto whose sound her Anthems now are sung,
Set them but out of tune, all is out of square,
Pull down the Church, and none can it repair,
But he that builds it: this is the faggot band
That binds all fast: undo it, undo the land --

sp.speaker: Card. omn.
sp.l: Most certain.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: You therefore (the best consort of the soul)
Shepherds (whose flocks are men, lambs, Angels,) you
That hold the roof of yon Star chamber up,
From dropping down to grind the world to dust,
You shall to Fairy land.

sp.speaker: Card. omnes.
sp.l: A joyful voyage.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Those that sing there the holy Hymns, as yet
Have not their voices clear, the stream of ceremony
Is scarcely settled, trouble it more: bait hooks
To take some, some to choake: cast out your net
At first, for all the fry: let us spread sails
To draw unto our shores the Fairy whales.
That Truth, whose standard-bearer Babylon,
And all we are, is not clean driven from thence,
Whither we send you: there she lives, but lives
A widow; steps not forth, dares not be seen
During her month of mourning: here we write you
How, and with whom to find her: what she bids,
That do: your hire is above.

sp.speaker: Card. omnes.
sp.l: We know it well.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: And when you see those Fairy fishermen
Row in your streams, when they grow cold in working,
And weary of their own waters, that the sails
(Which stiffly bear them up ) flag and hang low,
And that (like reeds, playing with a pair of winds.)
They promise facile pliancy, then, then shake
The trees by the root, then it will make the branches blow,
And drop their mellowed fruits, even at your feet,
Gather them they are our own, then is the hour,
To wean those sons of black Apostasy
From her. (their stepdame) and to make them take,
A blessing from our reverend mothers hands,
Be happy go.

sp.speaker: Card. omn.
sp.l: We shall remember you,
In all our kneelings.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Stay: ere you shift Air,
Sprinkle yourselves all over with sacred drops,
Take Periapts, Pentacles, and potent Charms
To conjure down foul fiends, that will be raised
To vex you, tempt you, and betray your blood,
About your necks hang hallowed Amulets,
That may Conserve you from the plagues of Error
Which will strike at you.

sp.speaker: Sacr. Omn.
sp.l: We obey most holy fathers.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.l: And hear you,
If climbing up to this haught enterprise
The foot slip, and ( in the fall) with death you meet --

sp.speaker: Sacr. Omn.
sp.l: O glorious ladder!

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.l: A Saints winding sheet,
Farewell: Mount all the engines of your wit
When darts are sent from all parts, some must hit.
There is a fellow to whom, because he dare
Not be a slave to greatness, nor is molded
Of Court dow (flattering) but (should it thunder)
To his father, doing ill, (would speak ill) our Empress,
Hath given this name. (Plain Dealing): this plain dealing
Have I shipped hence, and is long since arrived
Upon the fairy strand: from him I expect,
Intelligence of all Occurrences,
He for the names sake, shall perhaps be welcome,
Into that Harlots Company (whom the fairies
Think honest, and swear deeply, she is Truth.
That Strumpet by enticement he will bring over.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: It came to me in letters (two days since.
That this plain dealing serves the fairy Queen,
And will no more be seen in Babylon.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: How no more seen in Babylon, it is but one lost,
If Babylon subscribe to our wise-doom,
She shall lodge Double-Dealing in his room.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: We thought the fates would have closed up our eyes,
That we should never have seen this day-star rise:
How many plots were laid to bar us hence,
( Even from our Cradle?) but our Innocence
Your wisdom (fairy Peers) and above all,
That Arm) that cannot let a white soul fall,
Hath held us up, and lifted us thus hie,
Even when the Arrows did most thickly fly:
Of that bad woman, (Babylon's proud Queen,
Who yet (we hear ) swells with Envenomed Spleen.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Whose poison, shall (like Arrows shot upright)
When forth it bursts, to her own downfall light.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Truth be my witness (whom we have employed,
To purge our Air that has with plagues destroyed
Great numbers, shutting them in darksome shades)
I seek no fall of hers, my Spirit wades,
In Clearer streams; her blood I would not shed,
To gain that triple wreath that binds her head,
though mine she would let forth, I know not why,
Only through rank lust after Sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Enough it is for me, if with a hand,
(Unstained and un-ambitious) fairy Land
I Crown with Olive-branches: all those wounds,
Whose gory mouths but lately stained our Rounds,
Bleed yet in me: for when great Elfiline
(Our grandsire) filled this throne, your bowers did shine
With fire-red steel, and not with Fairies eyes,
You heard no music then, but shrieks and cries,
Then armed Urchins, and stern household Elves,
Their fatal pointed swords turned on themselves.
But when the royal Elfiline sat crowned,
These civil woes in their own depth lay drowned.
He to immortal shades being gone,
(Fames minion) great King Oberon
Titaniaes royal father, lively springs,
Whose Court was like a camp of none but Kings.
From this great conquering Monarchs glorious stem,
Three (in direct line) wore his Diadem:
A King first, then a pair of Queens, of whom,
She that was held a downcast, by Fates doom,
Sits now above their hopes: her maiden hand,
Shall with a silken thread guide Fairy land.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: And may she guide it,

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Even till stooping time
Cut for her ( down ) long years that she may climb
(With ease) the highest hill old age goes over,
Or till her Fairy subjects (that adore
Her birth-day as their being ) shall complain,
They are weary of a peaceful, golden reign.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Which, that they never shall, your stately towers
Shall keep their ancient beauty: and your bowers
(Which late) like profaned Temples empty stood,
The tops defaced by fire, the floors by blood,)
Shall be filled full of Choristers to sing
Sweet heavenly songs, like birds before the Spring:
The flowers we set, and the fruits by us sown,
Shall cheer as well the stranger as our own.
We may to strange shores once ourselves be driven,
For who can tell under what point of heaven
His grave shall open? neither shall our oaks,
Trophies of reverend Age, fall by our strokes,
Nor shall the brier, or hawthorn (growing under )
Fear them, but fly to them, to get from thunder,
And to be safe from foreign wildfire balls,
We will build about our waters wooden walls.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: On which we will spend for you our latest lives.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Fairies I thank you all, Stay who comes here?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Parthenophill, a Fairy Peer.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Parthenophill.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Bright Empress, Queen of maids
To us your Lords, amidst your Fairy shades:
Three Princes (so themselves they style) are come,
From whence, they will us not learn, and do entreat
Fair, and a free access.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: What is their business?

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: The splendour of your glories, which afar
Shines (as they say, and justly say) as brightly
As here at hand, hither them draws, protesting
All faith and service to you, and requesting
That they the tribute of their loves may pay,
At your most sacred feet.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Allow them entrance.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: They in a Fairy mask, the argument
Of this their duty, gladly would present.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: As best them please.

div1.stage: The Hault-boyes sounding, Titania in dumb show sends her Lords to fetch them in, who enter bare headed the three Kings quaintly attired like Masquers following them, who doing honour to her entreat to dance with her maids, and do so: This done they discover.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Your painted cheeks being off, your own discovers,
You are no Fairies.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.l: No: but wounded lovers.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: How! lovers! what! would you deflower my bed,
And strike off a poor maiden-head?
We know you not: what are you? and from whence?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: The land of whom the sun so enamoured is,
He lends them his complexion, gives me birth,
The Indian and his gold are both my slaves,
Upon my sword (as on the Axle tree)
A world of kingdoms move: and yet I write
Nonsufficit that lusty son of Ioue
That twelve times showed himself more than a man,
Reared up two pillars for me, on whose Capitals
I stand (Colossus-like) striding over seas,
And with my head knock at the roof of Heaven:
Hence come I, this I am, (O most divine)
All that I am is yours, be you but mine.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: The country at whose breast, hundreds of Kings
Have royally been fed, is nurse to me:
The god of grapes is mine, whose bounteous hand
In clusters deals his gifts to every land:
My Empire bears for greatness, policy,
State, skill in Arts and Arms, sole sovereignty
Of this Globe universal. All her Princes
Are warriors born: whose battles to be told,
Would make the hearers soldiers: it is a land
Of breath so sweet, and of aspect so fair,
That to behold her, and to conquer her,
(In amorous combats,) great king Oberon,
Your awful father, oft has thither come,
Like to a bridegroom, or a Reveller,
And gone again in goodly triumphs home.
From hence I spring, (fairest and most divine)
All that this is, is yours, be you but mine.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Be you but mine, and doubly will I treble
Their glories and their greatness: like to thunder
My voice far off, shakes kingdoms; whilst mine own
Stands on Seven hills, whose towers, and pinnacles,
And renarend Monuments, hold in them such worth,
And are so sacred, Emperors and Kings
(like barefoot pilgrims) at her feet do fall,
Bowing to her treble crown imperial.
The language which she speaks, goes through the world,
To prove that all the world should stoop to her,
And (save yourself ) they do; you think you leave
A rich inheritance, if to your sons,
Our fluent tongue you leave, (nor need they more)
Who speak and spend it well, cannot be poor:
On many nations necks, a foot to set,
If it be glorious, then may you be great.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: We are all pleased, so please you be the bride,
Of three, we care not which two be denied.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: For we are brethren, and those sacred breasts
From whence we draw our nourishment, would run
Nectar to you (sweet as the food of life:)
Our aged mother twenty times an hour,
Would breath her wholesome kisses on your cheek,
And from her own cup you should drink that wine
Which none but Princes taste, to make you look
With cheerful countenance.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You have a son,
Rebellious, wild, ingrateful, poor, and yet
Apollo from his own head cuts golden locks,
To have them grow on his: his harp is his,
The darts he shoots are his: the winged messenger
That runs on all the errands of the gods,
Teaches him swiftness he will outstrip the winds:
This child of yours is (by adoption)
Our mothers now, her blessing he receives;
And though (as men did in the golden Age)
He live in the open fields, hiding his head
In dampish caves, and woods, (sometimes for fear,)
Yet do we succour him. This your lost sheep,
We home again will bring, to your own fold,
Humbly to graze upon your Fairy plains,
Provided, that you sow them with such seed,
On which your whole land wholesomely may feed.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: We know you now: O what a deal of pains
Would you (as others of this wing have taken)
To be in Fairy land called Sovereigns?
Thanks for it: rashly nothing must we do:
When kingdoms marry, heaven itself stands by
To give the bride: Princes in tying such bands,
Should use a thousand heads, ten thousand hands:
For that one Act gives like an ingenious wheel
Motion to all, sets all the State a going,
And winds it up to height, or hurls it down,
The least blast turns the scale, where lies a crown:
We will therefore take advice. If these think fit
We should be yours, you ours, we sign to it:
Your counsel Fairy Lords: Fideli speak.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Would you (my royal mistress) have those crystal
Fair, double-leaved doors, where light comes forth
To cheer the world, never to open more?
Would you have all your slobbers turned to dreams,
Frightful and broken? would you see your Lords
(In stead of sitting at your Council boards)
Locking their grave, white, reverend heads in steel?
If so, you cannot for all Fairy land
Find men to fit you better.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Florimell,
Breathes there in you Fidelies spirit?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No Lady.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: No nor in any breast that is sound: true Councillor,
Already you speak music: you are strung
With golden chords; Angels guide on your tongue.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: These potent, politic, and twin born States,
Would to their mitred fortunes tie our fates:
Our Fairy groves are green, our temples stand
Like goodly watch-towers, wafting passengers
From rocks, to arrive them in the Holy land:
Peace (here) eats fruits, which her own had hath sown,
Your lambs with lions play: about your throne,
The Palm, the Laurel, and the abundant Vine
Grow up, and with your roses do entwine.
But if these gripe your Sceptre once,

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Vultures are not more ravenous than these men,
Confusion, tyranny, uproars will shake all,
Tigers, and wolves, and bears, will fill your seat,
In nothing (but in misery) you will be great:
Those black and poisonous waters that bore down
In their rough torrent, Fairy towns and towers,
And drowned our fields in Marianaes days,
Will (in a merciless inundation)
Cover all again: red Seas will flow again:
The Devil will roar again: if these you love,
Be (as the Serpent,) wise then, though a Dove.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: This he that speaks in music?

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Are you all,
Of this opinion Lords?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Let us hence.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: When close plots fail, use open violence.

sp.speaker: Titani.
sp.l: Stay: Princes are free-born, and have free wills,
These are to us, as valleys are to hills,
We may, be counselled by them, not controlled:
Our words our Law.

sp.speaker: Elfyr.
sp.l: Bright Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: You are too bold.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: I knew the fort would yield.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Attend.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: She is ours.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: You would Combine a League, which these would break.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: A League!

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Holy.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Honourable.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Nay hear me speak,
You court me for my love, you I embrace
As maids do Suitors, with a smiling face
As you do me: receive our answer then: --
I cannot love you: -- what! such hardy men
And fly for one repulse? I mean as yet;
As yet I am not at leisure: But I swear
Even by my birth-day, by the crown I wear,
By those sweet waters, which into us power
Health, that no sickness taints, by that blessed flower
Upon whose roseal stalk our peace does grow,
I swear I will my love on you bestow,
When one day comes, which now to you I will name.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: The time! O blessed time!

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Balm to our sorrow.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Name that most happy hour.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: May be tomorrow:
Mark else and judge whether it may or no:
When Lambs of ours, are killed by wolves of yours,
Yet no blood sucked: when Heaven two Suns endures:
When Souls that rest in undergrounds,
Hear Anthems sung, and praise the sounds:
When drops of water are so spilt,
That they can wash out murders guilt:
When Surgeons long since dead and gone.
Can cure our wounds, being called upon:
When from yon towers I hear one cry,
You may kill Princes lawfully:
When a Court has no Parasite,
When truth speaks false, and falsehood right:
When Conscience goes in cloth of gold,
When Offices are given; not sold.
When merchants wives hate costly clothes,
When there is no lies in tradesmen's oaths:
When Farmers by dear years do leese,
And Lawyers swear to take no fees:
(And that I hope will never, never be )
But then (and not till then) I swear,
Shall your bewitching Charms sleep in mine ear.
Away.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Derided to our faces!

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Baffled!

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Made fools!

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: This must not be.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: It shall not be.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Revenge:
Fly to our Empress bosom, there suck treason,
Sedition, Heresies confederacies,
The violation of all sacred leagues.
The combination of all leagues unjust,
The dispensation for sacramental oaths,
And when you are swollen with these, return again,
And let their poison rain down here in showers:
Whole herds of bulls laden with hallowed curses,
With Interdictions, excommunications,
And with unbinding Subjects fealties,
And with large patents to kill Kings and Queens
Drive roaring hither, that upon their horns
This Empire may be tossed.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: She shall be torn,
Even joint from joint: to have her baited well,
(If we cannot) we will unkennel hell:

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Will not you home with us?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: No: here I will lurk;
And in a Dove-like shape raven upon Doves:
I will suck allegiance from the common breast,
Poison the Courtier with ambitious drugs,
Throw bane into the cups where learning drinks,
I will be a Saint, a Fury, Angel, Devil,
Over Seas, on this side Seas; Devils foreigners,
With Devils within hell freedom, Devils in Vaults.
And with Church Devil, be it your souls health,
To drink down Babylonian Stratagems.
And to forge three-forked thunderbolts at home,
Whilst I melt Sulphur here: If the sweet bane
I lay be swallowed, O a Kingdom bursts,
But if the poisoned hook be spied, then levy
Eighty eight Legions, and take open arms,
The Guidon shall be mine, I will bear the Standard.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: It will be a glorious war.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Who cleaves a Realms head, needs more swords than one.

sp.speaker: Flory.
sp.l: These evil Spirits are vexed, and though they vanished
Like hideous dreams, yet have they left behind them,
Throbs, and heart achings, in the general bosom,
As ominous bodings. Fairy Lack eyes. --

sp.speaker: 4. Footmen.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Flory.
sp.l: Fly Sirrah through the Air and never rest
(On pain to be into an urchin turned)
Till thou hast fixed upon the highest gates,
Of our greatest Cities. There is a warning piece. Away.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: These to the Spirits that our waters keep,
Charge them that none rowest there, but those whose nets,
Are cast out of our Fairy gondolets. Away.

sp.speaker: Elfyr.
sp.l: These to the keepers of those royal woods
Where Lions, Panthers, and the kingly herds
Feed in one company; that if wild Boars,
Mad Bulls, or raving Bears, break in for prey,
Hoping to make our groves their wilderness,
Ours may like soldiers bid them battle. Fly.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: These to the Shepherds on our Fairy downs
To warn them not to sleep, but with sweet Lays
And Jolly pipings drive into fat pastures
Their goodly flocks: Wolves are abroad say, Fly.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: Place Providence, (because she has quick eye:
And is the best at kenning) in our Navy,
Courage shall wait on her.

div1.stage: Titania and her maids standing alofe.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No: she is most fit
To go with us.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Let her in Counsel sit.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: It is said: and least they break into our walks
And kill our fairy dear, or change themselves
Into the shape of Fawns, being indeed foxes,
Range all the forest danger to prevent,
Foresight, beats storms back, when most Imminent.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Titani.
sp.l: Wise Pilots? firmest pillars? how it agrees,
When Princes heads sleep on their counsels knees:
Deep rooted is a state, and grows up hie,
When Providence, Zeal, and Integrity
Husband it well: These fathers it will be said
(One day) make me a grandam of a maid.
Mean time my farewell to such gaudy lures
As here, were thrown up to have me quite overthrown,
I charge you maids, entertain no desires,
So irreligious and unsanctified:
O they have snakes sleeky tongues, but hearts more rugged
Than is the Russian Bear: our Fairy bowers
Would turn to Arabian deserts, if such flowers,
(Mortal as killing Hemlock) here should grow,
Which to prevent, I will have you vow.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: By the white balls in bright Titaniaes eyes,
We their enchantments scorn.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: It does suffice;
To bind it sure, Strew all your meads with charms,
Which if they do no good, shall do no harm.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Here comes your new sworn servant.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Now Sirrah, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: Where have I been? I have been in the bravest prison --

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: What prison? a brave prison? Can there be a brave prison?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: All your fine men live and die there, it is the Knights ward, and therefore must needs be brave: some call it an Ordinary, but I say it is a prison, for most of our gallants that are served every day with woodcocks there, lie there in a manner upon Execution: they dare not peep out of doors for fear of Sergeants.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: What are those Sergeants?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Do not you know (mistress) what Sergeants are? a number of your courtiers are dear in their acquaintance: why they are certain men-midwives, that never bring people to bed, but when they are sore in labour, that nobody else can deliver them.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: Are there such places in our kingdom, as Ordinaries, what is the true fashion of them, what is their order?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: They are out of all true fashion: they keep no order.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: Where about in Fairy land stand they?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: In your great city: and here is the picture of your Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: When Master Painter please we shall have it: come Sir.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Your gallants drink here right worshipfully, eat most impudently, dice most swearingly, swear most damnably, quarrel most desperately, and put up most cowardly. Suppose I were a young country gentleman, and that I were to come in (like an ass) among them, new cast into the bonds of satin.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Marry then do all the gilt rapiers turn their Tobacco faces in the room upon me, and they puff, they gape on a fresh man like so many stale Oysters at a full tide: then is there no salt to throw upon them, and to make them leave gaping, but this; to cast off his cloak, having good clothes underneath, single out some in the room worse accoutred than himself, with him to walk boldly up and down strutting, laugh aloud at anything, talk aloud of nothing, so they make a noise, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: You are grown sirrah an observer since you came out of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Troth mistress, I left villains and knaves there, and find knaves and fools here: for your Ordinary is your Isle of Gulles, your ship of fools, your hospital of incurable madmen: it is the field where your captain and brave man is called to the last reckoning, and is overthrown horse and foot: it is the only school to make an honest man a knave: for Intelligencers may hear enough there, to set twenty abegging of lands: it is the strangest Chess-board in the world.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Because in some games at Chess, knights are better than pawns, but here a good pawn is better than a knight.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: Afford our shores such wonders?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Wonders? why this one little Cockpit, (for none come into it, but those that have spurs) is able to show all the follies of your kingdom, in a few Apes of the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Have we not in our Land Physicians
To purge these red imposthumes?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p:
Troth yes mistress; but I am Plain dealing, and must speak truth, thou hast many Physicians, some of them sound men, but a number of them more sick at heart, than a whole parish full of Patients: let them cure themselves first, and then they may better know how to heal others: then have you other fellows that take upon them to be Surgeons, and by letting out the corruption of a State, and they let it out I will be sworn; for some of them in places as big as this, and before a thousand people, rip up the bowels of vice in such a beastly manner, that (like women at an Execution, that can endure to see men quartered alive) the
beholders learn more villainy than they knew before: others likewise there be of this consort last named, that are like Beadles bribed, they whip, but draw no blood, and of these I have made a Rime.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: Let us hear it.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: Those that do jerk these times, are but like fleas,
They bite the skin, but leap from the disease.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.p: I will have you Sir (because you have an eye so sharply pointed) to look through and through that our great City, and like death, to spare the lives of none, whose conscience you find sickly and going.

sp.speaker: Plain.
Titan.
sp.l: Do so, you shall no more to Babylon,
But live with us, and be our Officer.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Have I any kindred in your Court? is there anyone of my name an officer? if there be, part us because it will not be good, to have two of the Plain-dealings in one office, they will be beggars if they do.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: No Sirrah, we will provide you shall not want
Whilst us you serve. Go learn where Truth doth lie.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I have heard of her, she dwells (they say) at the sign of the Holy Lamb.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: We built her up a lodging at our cost,
To have her labour in our Vineyards:
For till she came, no Vines could please our taste,
But of her fining. Set your hand to hers,
Live with her in one house, fetch from our Court
Maintenance to serve you all: it will be to her
A comfort to have you still by her sides,
She has such pretty and delightful songs,
That you will count your forest labour light,
And time well spent only to hear her sing.
Away loose no more minutes.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Not a minute: I will set more watches than a clockmaker.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: What is yonder man that kneels?

sp.speaker: Elfi.
sp.l: It is Paridel

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Our doctor?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The most wretched in your land.
the most in soul dejected; the most base,
And most unserviceable weed, unless
You by your heavenly Influence change his values
Into a virtual habit fit for use.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: O we remember it; you are condemned?

sp.speaker: Elf.
sp.l: To Death.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: Deservedly.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: You had your hand
Not coloured with his blood.

sp.speaker: Elf.
sp.l: No dearest Lady
Upon my vowed Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: The law, hath fastened on me only for attempt,
It was no actual nor commenced violence
That brought death with it, but intent of ill.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: We would not save them, that delight to kill,
For so we wound ourselves: blood wrongly spilt
Who pardons, hath a share in half the guilt.
You struck, our laws not hard, yet what the edge
Of Justice could take from you, mercy gives you
(Your life.) You have it signed, rise.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: May yon Clouds
Muster themselves in Armies, to confound
Him that shall wish you dead, hurt, or uncrowned.
To run in debt thus basely for a life,
To spend which, had been glory! O most vile!
The good I reap from this superfluous grace,
Is but to make myself like Caesars horse,
To kneel whilst he gets up: my back must bear
Till the chine crack, yet still a servile fear
Must lay more loads on me, and press me down.
When Princes give life, they so bind men to them,
That trusting them with too much, they undo them.
Who then but I, from steps so low would rise?
Great fortunes (earned thus) are great Slaveries:
Snatched from the common hangman's hands for this?
To have my mind feele torture! now I see,
When good days come, (the Gods so seldom give them,)
That though we have them, yet we scarce believe them.
Heart how art thou confined? and bard of room,
Thou art quick enough, yet livest within a tomb.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: His name.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Campeius: Deeply learned.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: We hear so:
But with it hear (from some whom we have weighed
For judgment and experience) that he caries:
A soul within him framed of a thousand wheels
Yet not one steady.

sp.speaker: Parthe.
sp.l: It may be the rumour
That thus spreads over him, flows out of hate.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Believe us no: of his, and the others fate,
The threads are too unlike, to have that woven.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: To gain her crown I will not kneel thus.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Besides
The harvest which he seeks is reaped already:
We have bestowed it.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Here then dies our suit.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Now shall you try with what impatience
That bay tree will endure a little fire,
My Lord, my Lord,
Such swelling spirits hid with humble looks,
Are kingdoms poisons, hung on golden hooks,

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: I hope he will prove none such.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Such men oft prove.
Valleys that let in rivers to confound
The hills above them, though themselves lie drowned,
My Lord, I like not calm and cunning seas
That to have great ships taken or distressed,
Suffer base galleys to creep over their breast,
Let course hearts wear course skins: you know our will.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Which (as a doom divine) I shall fulfil.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Thrown down, or raised?

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: All hopes (for this) are gone,
Some planet stands in opposition.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Um: So.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Now Doctor Paridell.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: An humble suite,
I am grown bold finding so free a giver,
Where beggars once take alms, they look for it ever.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: You have been sworn our servant long.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Ten years.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: And we should wrong you; since you take us giving
To let you go with life, that should want living,
What is it we can grant you.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: I have been by two great Fairies in your land,
(Oppressed I dare not say) but so beaten down,
And sunk so low now with my last disgrace,
That all my happy thoughts lie in the dust,
Ashamed to look up yet: most humbly therefore
Beg I your gracious leave that I may vary,
This native Air for Foreign.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: O you would travel,
You may, you have our leave: Challenge our hand.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Storms are at Sea, when it is calm at land.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: The Sea-God hath upon your maiden shores,
(On Dolphins backs that pity men distressed)
In safety set a people that implores,
The Sovereign mercy flowing from your breast.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: What people are they?

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: Neighbours: it is the nation, The Netherlanders.
With whom our Fairies interchange commerce,
And by negotiation grown so like us,
That half of them are Fairies: the other half
Are hurtful Spirits, that with sulphurous breath
Blast their corn fields, deface their temples, cloth
their towns in mourning, poison hallowed founts,
And make their goodliest Cities stand (like tombs)
Full of dead bodies, or (like palaces,
From whence the Lords are gone) all desolate.
They have but seventeen daughters young and fair,
Vowed to live vestals, and to know the touch
Of any forced or unreverend hand.
Yet Lust and Avarice (to get their dowers)
Lay barbarous siege against their chastity,
Threaten to ravish them, to make their bodies
The temples of pollution, or their beds,
Graves where their honours shall lie buried,
They pray to have their virgins wait on you,
That you would be their mother, and their nurse,
Their Guardian and their Governor; when Princes
Have their lives given them, fine and golden threads
Are drawn and spun (for them) by the good fates,
That they may lift up others in low states.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Else let ourself decline; give them our presence:
In misery all nations should be kin,
And lend a brothers hand, usher them in.
Stood here my foes (distressed) thus would I grieve them,
Not how they have been, but how I might relieve them. Parthenophill.

sp.speaker: Path.
sp.l: Your good deeds (matchless Fairy) like the Sun,
(Rising but only in this point of heaven,
Spread through the world, So that a Prince (made wretched,
By his unhappy father, that lies slain
By barbarous swords, and in his gory wounds,
Drowns all the hopes of his posterity)
Hither, is like an orphan come (from far)
To get relief and remedy against those,
That would defeat him of his portion.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Pity and we had talk before you came,
She hath not taken yet her hand from ours,
Nor shall she part, until those higher powers
Behold that Prince: good works are theirs, not ours;
Go: bid him trust his misery in our hands,
Great trees I see do fall, when the shrub stands.

div1.stage: Fideli Florimell the states of the countries, Parthenophill Elfyron, the Prince of Portugal. To the States.

stage.foreign: Auxilio tutos dimittam, opibusque Iuuabo. Non ignara mali, miseris succurrere disco.

div1.stage: The third King to the King of Portugall.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Stands my beard right? the gown I must look grave,
White hairs like silver clouds a privilege have,
Not to be searched, or be suspected foul:
Make away those two turn coats. Suite me next
Like to a Satin devil (bravely) fly
Your sails shape: be here immediately.
So: excellent: a subtle masque: all is fit,
This very cap makes my head swell with wit.
Amongst soldiers, I have played the soldier,
Been mutinous, railed at the State, cursed peace:
They walk with cross-arms, gaping for a day,
Have under-shored their eye-lids (like trap windows.)
To keep them open, and with yawning ears,
Lie listening on flock bolsters, till rebellion
Beat up her drum: this lards me fat with laughter,
Their swords are drawn half way, and all those throats
That are to bleed are marked: and all those doors,
Where civil Massacres, murders (died in grain)
Spoil, riflings, and sweet ravishments shall enter,
Have tokens stamped on them (to make them known)
More dreadful than the Bills that preach the plague:
From them, with oiled hams (lapped in servile blue)
I stole, and filled out wine of Babylon,
To live things (made of clods) poor country sots,
And drunk they are: whole shires with it do reel,
Poisons run smooth, because men sweetness feele.
Now to my schoolmen, Learnings fort is strong,
But poorly manned, and cannot hold out long
When golden bullets batter. -- Yonder is one --
You are a poor scholar?

sp.speaker: Campeius.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: What read you?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: A book.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: So learned, yet so young?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Ye may see Sir.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You feed some discontent?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Perhaps I have cause.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: What troubles you?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: You trouble me: pray leave me.

sp.speaker: 3. Kin.
sp.l: Put yourself, and your grief into my hands.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Say ye?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Put yourself and your grief into my hands.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Are you a Doctor? your hands Sir, pray why?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You know me not.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Do you know yourself? your business?
Are you a scholar?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Judge of that by these.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: O Sir, I have seen many heads under such wool,
That scarce had brains to line it: if ye are a scholar,
Methinks you should know manners, by your leave Sir.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Pray leave your name behind you.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Name, Campeius.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Campeius! um: Campeius? a lucky planet
strikes out this hour: Campeius! Babylon,
His name hath in her tables: on his forehead,
Our Queen hath set her mark: it is a mold
Fit to cast mischief in: none sooner rent
A Church in two, than Scholars discontent.
I must not loose this Martin's nest, -- once more
Ye are happily met.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: This bur still hang on me!
And you Sir.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Tell me pray, did you never taste -- I am bold -- did you never taste
Those clear and redolent fountains that do nourish,
In vive and fresh humidity those plants
That grow on the other side (our opposites)
Those that to us here, are the Antipodes,
Clean against us in grounds -- you feele me -- say
Never drunk you of that nectar.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: I wish you had, I gather from your eyes,
What your disease is, I have been yourself,
This was Campeius once ( though not so learned)
For I was bred (as you) in Fairy Land,
A Country! well but it is our country: and so,
Good to breed beggars. She starves Arts: fats fools,
She sets up drinking rooms, and pulls down schools.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: So Sir.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: No more but so Sir? this discourse
Palates not you.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Nothing hath passed me
I hope, against my country, or the State,
That any you can take hold of.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: If they could,
It is but mine Aye, to your no.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You are too sour:
Unmellowed: you stand here in the shade,
Out of the warmth of those blessed ripening beams, --
Go to -- I grieve that such a blossom --

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Sir, I know you not: this thing which you have raised,
Affrights me: scholars of weak temper need
To fear (as they on Sunbanks lie to read)
Adders in the highest grass: these leaves but turned,
Like willow sticks hard rubbed may kindle fire,
Cities with sparks as small have oft been burned.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Do you take me for a hangman?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: I would be loath,
For any harsh tune that my tongue may warble,
To have the instrument unstrung.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You shall not:
Welfare unto you.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: And to you. A word Sir:
Bred in this country?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: I am no bird
To break mine own nest down: what flight soever
Your words make through this air ( though it be troubled)
Mine ear Sir, is no reaching Fowling piece
What passes through it, kills: you may proceed,
Perhaps you would wound that, I wish should bleed.
You have the advantage now,
I put the longest weapon into your hands.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: It shall guard you:
You draw me by this line: let us private walk.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: This path is unbruised: go on Sir.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Sir I love you.
The Dragons that keep learnings golden tree,
As you now have, I fought with, conquered them,
Got to the highest bough, eat of the fruit,
And gathered of the seven-fold leaves of Art,
What I desired; and yet for all the Moons
That I have seen wax old, and pine for anger,
I had outwatched them: and for all the candles
I wasted out on long, and frozen nights,
To thaw them into day; I filled my head
With books, but scarce could fill my mouth with bread;
I had the Muses smile, but monies frown,
And never could get out of such a gown.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: How did you change your star?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: By changing Air:
The god of waves washed off my poverty,
I sought out a new sun beyond the seas,
Whose beams begat me gold.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: O me dull ass!
I am nailed down by wilful beggary,
Yet feele not where it enters: like a horse
My hooves are pared to the quick) even till they bleed
To make me run from hence, yet this Tortoise shell,
(My country) lies so heavy on my back,
Pressing my worth down, that I slowly creep
Through base and slimy ways.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Country!

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: She hangs
Her own brats at her back, to teach them beg,
And in her lap sets strangers.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Yet your country.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: I was not born to this, not schooled to this,
My parents spent not wealth on me to this,
I will not stay here long.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Do not.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Being hence,
I will write in gall and poison against my nurse
This Fairy land, for not rewarding merit:
If ever I come back I will be a Calthrop
To prick my countries feet, that tread on me.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: O she is unkind, hard-hearted!

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: In disputation
I dare for latin, hebrew, and the greek,
Challenge an university; yet (O evil hap!)
Three learned languages cannot set a nap
Upon this thread-bare gown: how is Art cursed?
She has the sweetest limbs, and goes the worst:
Like common Fiddlers, drawing down others meat
With liquorish tunes, whilst they on scraps do eat.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Shake then these servile fetters off.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: But how?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Play the mules part, now thou hast sucked a dam
Dry and unwholesome, kick her sides.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Her heart -- her very heart --
Would it were dried to dust, to strew upon
The invenomed paper upon which I will write.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Know you the Court of Babylon?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: I have read,
How great it is, how glorious, and would venture
A soul to get but thither.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Get then thither; you venture none, but save
a soul going thither:
The Queen of Babylon rides on a beast,
That carries up seven heads.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Rare.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Each head crowned.

div1.stage: Enter his man like a sailor with rich attires under his arm.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: O admirable!

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: She with her own hand
Will fill thee wine out of a golden bowl.
There is Angels to conduct thee. Get to sea,
Steal over, behold, here is one to waft thee hence,
Take leave of none, tell none, thou art made, farewell.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Thus to meet heaven, who would not wade through hell?
Exeunt Campeius and Sailor, manet 3. King, enter Sailor presently.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: To flea off this hypocrisy, it is time,
Least worn too long, the Foxes skin be known:
In our dissembling now we must be brave,
Make me a courtier come; Asses I see,
In nothing but in trappings, different be
From foot-cloth nags, on which gay fellows ride,
Save that such gallants gallop in more pride.
Away. Stow under hatches that light stuff:
It is to be worn in Babylon.
At this grove,
And much about this hour, a slave well moulded,
In profound, learned villainy, gave oath
To meet me: Art thou come! Can thy black Art
This wonder bring to pass?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: See, it is done.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Titania's picture right.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This virgin wax,
Bury I will in slimy putrid ground,
Where it may piecemeal rot: As this consumes,
So shall she pine, and (after languor) die.
These pins shall stick like daggers to her heart,
And eating through her breast, turn there to gripings
Cramp-like Convollions, shrinking up her nerves,
As into this they eat.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Thou art famed for ever,
If these thy holy labours well succeed,
Statues of molten brass shall rear thy name,
The Babylonian Empress shall thee honour.
And (for this) each day shalt thou go in chains.
Where wilt thou bury it?

sp.speaker: Coniur.
sp.l: On this dunghill.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Good:
And bind it down with most effectual charms,
That whosoever with unhallowed hands,
Shall dare to take it hence, may rave and die.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Leave me.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Farewell and prosper: be blind you skies,
You look on things unlawful with sore eyes.

div1.stage: Dumb show. The Hault-boyes sound, and whilst hee is burying the picture, Truth and Time enter, Fideli, Parthenophil, Elstron, and a Guard following aloof. They discover the fellow, hee is taken, the picture found, hee kneels for mercy, but they making signs of refusal, he snatcheth at some weapon to kill himselfe, is prevented, and led away.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Who sets those tunes to mock us? Stay them.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Peace there.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: No more: your music must be dumb.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: When those Celestial bodies that do move,
Within the sacred Spheres of Princes bosoms
Go out of order, it is as if yon Regiment,
Were all in uproar: heaven should then be vexed,
Methinks such indignation should resemble,
Dreadful eclipses, that portend dire plagues
To nations, fall to Empires, death to Kings,
To Cities devastation, to the world,
That universal hot calamity
Of the last horror. But our royal blood,
Beats in our veins like seas struggling for bounds,
Aetna, burns in us: bearded Comets shoot
Their vengeance through our eyes: our breath is lightning,
Thunder our voice, yet, as the idle Cannon,
Strikes at the Aires Invulnerable breast)
Our darts are flipped back in mockery,
Wanting the points to wound.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Too near the heart,
(Most royal Empress) these distempers fit,
So please you, we will again assail her beauty
In varied shapes, and work on sutler Charms,
Again loves poisoned arrows we will let fly.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No: proud spirits once denying, still deny.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.l: Then be yourself, (a woman) change those overtures:
You made to her of an unusual peace,
To an unused defiance: give your revenge,
A full and swelling sail, as from your greatness
You took, in veiling to her: you have been
Too cold in punishment, too soft in chiding,
And like a mother (cause her years are green)
Have winked at Errors, hoping time, or council,
Or her own guilt (seeing how she goes awry,)
Would straighten all. -- you find the contrary.

sp.speaker: Empe.
sp.l: What follows?

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Sharp chastisement, leave the Mother
And be the stepdame; wanton her no more
On your Indulgent knee, sign no more pardons
To her Off-fallings and her flyings out,
But let it be a meritorious Act:
Make it a ladder for the soul to climb,
Lift from the hinges all the gates of heaven;
To make way for him that shall kill her.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Give him an office in yon Star-chamber,
Or else a Saints place and Canonise him;
So Sanctify the arm that takes her life,
That silly souls may go on pilgrimage,
Only to kiss the Instrument (that strikes)
As a most reverent relic.

sp.speaker: Empe.
sp.l: Be it so.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: In that one word she expires

sp.speaker: Empe.
sp.l: (That play the Pilots now, and steer her kingdom
In foulest weather) as white bearded corn
Bows his proud head before the imperial winds,
Shall so lie grovelling ( here ) when that day comes.

sp.speaker: 1. Ki.
sp.l: And that it shall come fates themselves prepare.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: True, but old Lions hardly fall into the snare.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Is not the good and politic Satyran
(Our leagued brother, and your vassal sworn)
Even now (this very minute) sucking close
Their fairest bosoms? if his trains take well:
They have strange workings (down-wards) into hell.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: That Satiran is this hand: his brains a forge
Still working for us he is the true set clock
By which we go, and of our hours doth keep
The numbered strokes, when we lie bound in sleep.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Besides such voluntaries as will serve
Under your holy colours and forsake
The Fairy standard, all such fugitives
Whose hearts are Babylonized: all the Mutineers
All the damned Crew, that would for gold tear off
The devils beard: All scholars that do eat
The bread of sorrow, want, and discontent,
Wise Satryan takes up, presses, apparels,
Their backs like Innocent Lambs, their minds like wolves,
Rubs over their tongues with poison, which they spat
Against their own anointed; their own Country,
Their very parent. And thus ships them hither,
To make them yours.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: To use.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Only to employ them
As Bees whilst they have stings, and bring thighs laden
With honey, hive them, when they are drones, destroy them.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: The earnest which he gives you (adored Empress,)
Are three fit engines for us.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Are they wrought?

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: They are: and wait in Court your utmost pleasure,
Out of your Cup made we them drunk with wines,
To sound their hearts, which they with such devotion
Received down, that even whilst Bacchus, swam
From lip to lip, in midst of taking healths,
They took their own damnation, if their blood
(As those grapes) streamed not forth, to effect your good.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Let us behold these fireworks, that must run
Upon short lines of life: yet will we use them,
Like instruments of music play on them,
A while for pleasure, and then hang them by,
Who Princes can upbraid, it is good they die.
For as in building sumptuous palaces,
We climb by base and slender scaffoldings,
Till we have raised the Frame: and that being done,
(To grace the work) we take the Scaffolds down,
So must we these: we know they love us not,
But Swallow-like when their own summers past,
Here seek for heat: or like flight Travellers,
(Swollen with vainglory, or with lust to see,)
They come to observe fashions and not me.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: As Travellers use them then, till they be gone,
Look Cheerfully; backs turned, no more thought upon.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What are they that fly hither (to our bosom)
But such as hang the wing, such as want nests;
Such as have no sound feathers; birds so poor,
They scarce are worth the killing: with the Lark
(The morning's falconer) so they may mount hie,
Care not how base and low their risings be?
What are they but lean hungry Crows that tire
Upon the mangled quarters of a Realm?
And on the house-tops of Nobility
(If there they can but sit) like fatal Ravens,
Or screech-owls croak their falls and hoarsely bode,
Nothing but scaffolds and unhallowed graves?

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Fitter for us: yet sit they here like doves.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: True: like corrupted Churchmen they are doves,
That have eat carrion: home we will therefore send
These busy-working Spiders to the walls
Of their own country, when their venomous bags
(Which they shall stuff with scandals, libels, treasons)
Are full and upon bursting: let them there
Weave in their politic looms nets to catch flies;
To us they are but Pothecary drugs,
Which we will take as Physical pills, not food:
Use them as lancets to let others blood,
That have foul bodies, care not whom you wound,
Nor what parts you cut off, to keep this sound.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Here come they.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Welcome: rise, and rise up high
In honours and our favour: you have thrust
Your arms into our coffers, have you not?

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Yes sacred Empress.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: And into our own,
Have rained down showers of gold.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: You shall deserve it:
You see what Ocean can replenish you,
Be you but duteous tributary streams:
But is your temper right? are not the edges
Of your sharpe spirits rebated? are you ours?
Do not your hearts sink down yet? will you on?

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Stood death in the way.

sp.speaker: Lup.
sp.l: Stood hell.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Nobly resolved:
But listen to us and observe our counsel:
Back must we send you to the Fairy Land,
Danger goes with you; here is your safety: listen.
Choose winds to sail by; if the wayward seas
Grow stormy, hover, keep aloof: if fears,
Shipwrecks, and death lie tumbling on the waves,
And will not off, then on: be venturous,
Conquests hard got are sweet and glorious.
Being landed, if suspicion cast on you
Her narrow eyes, turn yourselves then to Moles,
Work under ground, and undermine your country,
Though you cast earth up but a handful high,
To make her stumble: if that bloodhound hunt you,
(That long-eared Inquisition) take the thickets,
Climb up to Haymows, live like birds, and eat
The undeflowered corn: in hollow trees
Take such provision as the Ant can make:
Fly with the Bat under the eaves of night,
And shift your nests: or like to Anchorites,
Close up yourselves in artificial walls:
Or if you walk abroad, be wrapped in clouds,
Have change of hairs, of cie-brows, halt with soldiers,
Be shaven and be old women, take all shapes
To escape taking: But if the air be clear,
Fly to the Court, and underneath the wings
Of the Eagle, Falcon, or some great bird hover,
Oaks and large Beech-trees many, beasts do cover.
He that first sings a Dirge tuned to the death
Of that my only foe the Fairy Queen,
Shall be my love, and (clad in purple) ride
Upon that scarlet-coloured beast that bears
Seven Kingdoms on seven heads.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: If all the Spells
That wit, or eloquence, or arts can set:
If all the sleights that bookmen use in schools
Be powerful in such happiness, it is mine.

sp.speaker: Rop.
sp.l: What physic can I dare only to grow
(But as I merit shall) up in your eye.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: We will erect ladders for you strong and high,
That you shall climb to starry dignity.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We take our leave dread Empress.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Fare you well:
Our benediction go along with you --
Our malediction and your souls confusion
Like shivered towers fall on your luckless heads,
And wedge you into earth low as the deep
Where are the damned, if our world you fire,
Since desperately you will ride and dare aspire.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: But is this all? shall we thus bend our sinews
Only to empty quivers, and to shoot
Whole sheafs of forked arrows at the Sun,
Yet never hit him?

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.l: And the mark so fair!

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Nay, which is more, suppose that all these terrets
Which from your sea of Greatness, you (for your part)
And all those straggling floods which we have driven
With full and stiff winds to the Fairy Strands,
Should all break in at once, and in a deluge
Of Innovation, rough rebellion, factions,
Of massacres, and pale destruction
Swallow the kingdom up, and that the blood
Even of Titania's heart should in deep crimson
Dye all these waters: what of this? what share
Is yours? what land shall you recover?

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: All!

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Aye, all:
Between the Transversaries that do run
Upon this cross staff, a dull eye may find
In what degree we are, and of what height
Yourself (our brightest Ariadne) is,
Being underneath that Tropic: as those jewels
Of night and day are by alternate course
Worn in Heavens fore-head,
So when Deaths Winter comes,
And shortens all those beams of Majesty,
Which in this oblique and Zodiacal Sphere
Move with Titania now, shall loose their heat,
Where must the next Sun rise but here? from whence
Shall Fairy land get warmth? merely from hence.
Let but the taper of her life burn out,
We have such torches ready in her land
To catch fire from each other, that the flames
Shall make the frighted people think earth burns,
And being dazzled with our Copes of Stars,
We shall their temples hallow with such ease,
As it were in solemn gay procession.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Some line sea cards, that know not the seas taste,
Nor scarce the colour: by your charms I gather
You have seen Fairy land -- but in a Map:
Can tell how it stands: but if you give it a fall,
You must get bigger bones: for let me whisper
This to your ear; though you bait hooks with gold,
Ten thousand may be nibbling, when none bites,
And those you take for Angels, you will find Sprites.
Say that Titania were now drawing short breath,
(As that is the Cone and Button that together
Clasps all our hopes) out of her ashes may
A second Phoenix rise, of larger wing,
Of stronger talent, of more dreadful beak,
Who swooping through the air, may with his beating
So well command the winds, that all those trees
Where sit birds of our hatching (now fled thither)
Will tremble, and (through fear struck dead) to earth,
Throw those that sit and sing there, or in flocks
Drive them from thence, yea and perhaps his talent
May be so bony and so large of gripe,
That it may shake all Babylon.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: All Babylon!

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Your pardon: but who will swear this may not be?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How the prevention?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Thus; to fell down their Q. is but one stroke;
Our axe must cleave the kingdom, that is the Oak.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The manner.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Easy: whilst our thunderbolts
Are anviling abroad, call Satyran home,
He in his fathom metes vast Argosies,
Huge Galleasses, and such wooden Castles,
As by enchantment of the waters move:
To his, marry yours and ours; and of them all
Create a brave Armada, such a Fleet,
That may break Neptunes back to carry it:
Such for variety, number, puissance,
As may fetch all the Fairy Land in turfs,
To make a green for you to walk upon
In Babylon.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Invincible! go on.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Now when the volley of those murdering shot
That are to play first on Titaniaes breast,
And (yet) lean on their rests, go off and kill her,
So that the very Aluerado given,
Sounds the least hope of conquest; then, then show
Your warlike Pageants dancing on the waves,
Yours is the Land, the Nation are your slaves.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Counsel from Heaven!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: None this shall overwhelm:
Brave voyage! Rig out ships, and fetch a Realm.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You arrive on a blessed shore. The freight you bring
Is good: it will be bought up of us all
With our dear bloods: be constant, do not warp
In this your zeal to Babylon.

sp.speaker: Paryd.
sp.l: Grave Palmio,
To you I have unladen even my soul,
The wings from home that brought me had sick feathers,
Some you have pulled off: my own country grass
Was to my feet sharpe needles (stuck upright)
I tread on down beds now.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: But are your countrymen
(I mean those that in thought with us feast richly)
Fed with the course bread of affliction still?

sp.speaker: Paryd.
sp.l: Still father Palmio still, and to relieve them
I dare do what I told you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Noble valour!

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: So that I might but read on yonder scrolls,
A warrant writ under the seal of Heaven,
To justify the Act.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: You have my hand,
And shall have more. You are reconciled ( Son: )

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Who did confess you?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Father Anniball.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: But did the Nuncio Campeggio
Present your letters, and your vowed service
At Babylon.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: He did: I sued out warrant
For passage safely thither: and from grave Como
(One of the capital Columns of the state)
This I received.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: He sends you here good welcome:
It is strong; why went you not?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: I like it not:
There wants a convoy of some better words,
Which hourly I expect: upon a Sea
So dangerous, so full of rocks, so narrow,
(Albeit the venture holy and of honour)
I would not gladly sail, without direction
Of noble Pilots, home I would not come
Basely, but like a glorious voyager.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Yea, you do well; the Nuncio Raggazoni!
Not know him?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Certes no.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Come, you shall meet:
Monsignor, here is a Gentleman desires
To have your arms about him. --

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: He undertakes an action full of merit,
Sans promise or reward, to cure all those
Through Fairy land, that are diseased within,
And he will do it, by letting one vein blood.

sp.speaker: Ragaz.
sp.l: Shoots he at highest?

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Draw home, and give
Your arrows compass, that until they fall
Full on the head, none see them: you do well:
My hands are yours: good speed. --

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Campeggio?
Now shall you hear some news.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: I do assure you,
The Mistress of us all, hath on this paper
Breathed you a blessing: your devotion
Is recommended highly, and to nourish
The flames new kindled in you, here is more fuel,

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.p: Licence to go and come, in verbo imperatricis per omnes Iurisdictiones Babilonicas absque impedimento .
sp.l: Good: would it had come sooner.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: It is general,
Exceeding absolute and peremptory.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: It gives me my full sail: but by deep vows,
I am to travel lower, yet if season
Beat me not back, I will to Babylon,
What rubs soever I meet in letters still,
I will kiss her sacred hand.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.l: You change not bias.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: O good sir, yonder is the goal I run for!

div1.stage: Raggazoni at one door, a Gentleman at another.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Lend me your speeches both.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yonder comes one of your own country.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: O I know him Sir.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Walk in this college class but some few minutes,
I will send or bring to you a Gentleman,
Next neighbour to your country: an Albanois --
The man I told you of.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Thanks Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Met happily, I looked for you.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Dear countryman the parley we late held
About the land that bred us, as how order
Was robbed of ceremony (the rich robe of order)
How Truth was freckled, spotted, nay made leprous:
How Justice --

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, no more.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Even now (as then)
You ward blows off from her, that at all weapons
Strikes at your head: but I repent we drew not
That dialogue out to length, it was so sweet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: At hours more opportune we shall: but countryman
I heard of late the music of my soul,
And you the instrument are made that sounds it:
It is given me, that yourself hath sealed to heaven
A bond of your devotion, to go forth
As champion of us all, in that good quarrel,
That hath cost many lives.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: What need we use
Circumgirations, and such wheeling? Sir,
Believe it, to recover our sick Nurse
I would kill the noblest foster-child she keeps.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I know what bird you mean, and who you hate,
But let him stand to fall: no sir, the Dear
Which we all hope you will strike, is even the pride
And glory of the Forest: So, or not?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: My vows are flown up, and it must be done,
So this may be but settled.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Do you stagger?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: All winds are not yet laid.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Have you looked out
For skilful coasters, that know all the sounds,
The flats, and quick sands, and can safely land you
Out of all touch of danger?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: I have met many,
And like a consort they hold several tunes --

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But make they music?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Faith a little jarring:
Sometimes a string or so: yet reverend Palmio,
And Anniball a Codreto keep the stream
In which I swim: the Nuncio Ragazzoni
Plies me with wholesome physic; so the Nuncio,
My honoured Friend Campeggio makes it clear,
That it is lawful.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Where at stick you then?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: At a small rock, (a dispensation.)

div1.stage: Raggazzoni, Palmio, Campeggio, and the Albonoys.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You cannot want for hands to help you forward:
In such a noble work your friends are near;
Dear Countryman, my sword, my state, and honour,
Are for your use, go on; and let no heat
thaw your strong resolution, I shall see you,
Before you take to Sea.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: My duty.

sp.speaker: Pai.
sp.l: This is the worthy Gentleman, to whom
I wish your love endeared: we have some conference.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Born Sir in Fairy Land?

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: No marry Sir -- An Albanois,

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Then for proximity
Of Countries, let us interchange acquaintance,
I wished for your embracements, for your name
Is crowned with titles of integrity,
Judgment and Learning: let me upon their Bases
Erect a pillar, by which Babylon,
And all we may be strengthened.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I pray be apert and plain.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Then thus Sir; by the way of Argument
I would a question put, to taste your censure,
Because I do not soundly relish it.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Propone it Sir, I will solve it as I can.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Suppose that in the field there were an Army,
Commixed of half your kinsfolk, friends, and lovers,
The other half sworn foes, (all countrymen;)
And that the leader of them were your father,
And that this leading father were so partial,
That to preserve that half which loves you not,
Ye would loose that which loves you: and that to take
This Captains life away, might bring this good,
Of two sides to make one, and save much blood:
Would not you do it.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Um: you are full of Ambage:
I answer as my spirits lead me, thus,
I would not do it.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Why Sir.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Because I hold, Quod non omnino Licet .

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Come, Come, I know (without all commenting)
This text you understand: weigh the utility,
That goes with it: the health it gives to thousands;
The sap it spreads through branches which now wither:
The restoration --

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Sir I see to the bottom,
Of this deep well you dive in: I do arm you,
In this strong fight, just with the self same weapons
Which I would wear to guard me, and those are
My readings and belief settled by reading,
And this I find. Quod non sunt facieda mala, vt veniant bona
For good; (how great so ever ) must be done,
no ill how small soever.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: It is no evil.
To bar out so great ill, with so great good.

sp.speaker: Alba.
