sp.p: All good must not be done, but only that -- Quod bene et legitime fieri potest : For Sir I know, that Deus magis amat aduerbia quam nomina. Quia in actionibus magis et Placent Bene et legitime quam bonum. It a vt nullum bonum Liceat sacere, nisi bene et legitime fieri potest. Quod in hoc Casu fieri non potest .

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Yet (with your favour) several learned men,
Are clean from your opinion, and do hold, Quod licet.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Those learned men perhaps may hold it fit,
That to save many, they to one man's danger,
(Referring all to the depth inscrutable)
May allow of a particular; on no warrant
That they can show me written, but being stirred,
With a human compassion to men's lives:
And less you revelation have divine,
That bids you do, do not; Thus you have mine.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What so hard at it.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: We have done: the time,
Does pull me from your sweet society,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You will to Babylon.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: I cannot tell;
Whether I do or no, you shall have notice,
How this great work goes forward; strengthen me,
With all your comforts, and commend my service
To the most glorious throne: if I get over,
There lands black vengeance on the Fairy shore.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: If prayers can do it shall.

sp.speaker: Pay.
sp.l: But how shall I know, thou art the right truth?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Because I am not painted.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Nay if thou hast no better colour than that, there is no truth in thee, for I am sure your fairest wenches are free of the painters.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Besides I am not gorgeous in attire,
But simple, plain and homely; in mine eyes,
Doves sit, not Sparrows: on my modest cheeks,
No witching smiles do dwell: Upon my tongue
No unchaste language lies: my skin is not spotted
With foul disease, as is that common harlot,
That base-born truth, that lives in Babylon.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why? is she spotted?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: All over, with strange ugliness, all over,

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Then she has got the pox, and lying at my host Gryncums, since I left her company: how soever it be thou and I will live honest together in one house, because my court mistress will have it so: I have been a Travailer a great while, plain dealing hath leapt from country to country, till he had scarce a pair of soles to carry him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why? in what Countries have you been?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: In more than I had mind to stay in; I have been amongst the Turkes too, the Turkes made as much of poor plain dealing, as those whom we call Christians.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What man is that great Turke? I never saw him:

sp.speaker: Par.
Tru.
sp.p: Where had you been, when now you met with me.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Looking up and down for thyself: and yet I lie too, now I remember, I was in the city: our mistress would needs have me go thither, to see fashions: I could make an excellent Taylor for Ladies and gentlemen, and fools, for I have seen more fashions there, than a picture drawer makes scurvy faces, the first two years of his trade: it is the maddest circle to conjure in, that ever raised spirit.

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.p: Tell me good kinsman, what in the city saw you?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: What did I see? why I will tell thee cozen; I saw no more conscience in most of your rich men, than in Tavern faggots: nor no more soberness in poor men, than in Tavern spigots: I see that citizens fine wives undo their husbands (by their pride) within a year after they are married; and within half a year after they be widows, knights undo them: they will give a hundred pound to be dubbed ladies, and to ride in a coach, when they have scarce another hundred pound left to keep the horses. But cuz Truth, I met in one street a number of men in gowns, with papers in their hands, what are all those?

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: O! they are the sons of Justice; they are those
That beat the kingdom level, keep it smooth
And without rubs: they are the poor man's captain,
The rich man's soldier, and called Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: Lawyers? dost know any of them?

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: A few.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: I wondered what they were, I asked one of them if they were going to foot-ball, yes said he, do you not see those country fellows, we are against them; and who do you think shall win, said I, O said he, the gowns, the gowns.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Follow me Truth; Plain dealing follow me.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: He charges like a Constable; come, we are his watch: follow me? Is our Time mad?
sp.l: O brave mad Time.

div1.stage: Dumb show. A cave suddenly breakers open, and out of it comes Falsehood, (attired as Truth is) her face spotted, shee sticks vp her banner on the top of the Cave; then with her foot in several places strikes the earth, and vp riseth Campeius; a Friar with a box: a gentleman with a drawn sword, another with rich gloves in a box, another with a bridle, Time, Truth with her banner, and Plain-dealing enter & stand aloof beholding all.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: See there is the Cave, where that Hyena lurks,
That counterfeits thy voice, and calls forth men
To their destruction.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: How full of the small pox she is, what ails she to stamp thus? is the whore mad? how now? Yea do you rise before Dooms day; father Time, what conduit-pipes are these, that break out of the earth thus?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: The conduit-heads of treason, which convey
Conspiracies, scandals, and civil discord,
Massacres, poisonings, wrecks of faith and fealty
Through Fairies hearts, to turn them into elves:
See Truth, see son, the snake slips off his skin,
A scholar makes a ruffian.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: Now must that ruffian cuff the scholar, if I were as he.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: And see, that snap which erst showed reverend,
And wore, the outward badge of sanctity,
Is clothed in garments of hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Plaine.
sp.l: See, see, father, he has a jack in a box: what is that?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: A wild beast, a mad bull, a bull that roars,
To fright allegiance from true subjects bosoms;
That Bull must bellow, at the Flamens gate:
His gate, that tends the flocks of all those sheep,
That graze in the fattest pasture of the land,
Being all enclosed: that bull will on his back
Bear all.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: Whither? whither?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: To hell: it is said to heaven
That will but sit him, till with hoof or horn,
He gore the anointed Fairy.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Such Bulls have I seen sent out of Babylon, to run at people: I should once have rid upon one of them, but he that begged my office, broke his neck by the bargain, and saved me a labour: what is he with the sword, a master of the noble Science?

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: A noble villain: see, he pulls down heaven
With imprecations, if that blade he sheath not,
In our sweet mistress breast.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: O rogue! what good clothes he wears, and yet is a villain?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Aye, do: clap hands upon it, that poisoned glove,
Shall strike thee dead to death, with the strong sent
Of thy discovered treason.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.l: What is that horse-courser with the bridle?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: A slave, that since he dares not touch her head,
Would work upon her hand: -- laugh and conspire;
The higher villains climb, they fall the higher.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Stay father, now the Army comes forward: she takes down the flag, belike their play is done; what will she bear the colours? thou hast colour enough in thy face already, thou needst no more: did ye ever see a more lousy band? there is but two rapiers in the whole regiment: now they muster, now they double their files: mark how their hands juggle, and lay about; this is the maine battle: O well flourished Ancient! the day is theirs; see, now they sound retreat: whither march they now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: To death; their falls, thus Time and Truth proclaim,
They shall like leaves drop from the Tree of shame.
Let us follow them.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: To the gallows? not I; what do we know, but this freckled face quean, may be a witch.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: She is so; she is that damned sorceress,
That keeps the enchanted towers of Babylon.
This is the Truth, that did bewitch thee once.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Is this speckled toad she? She was then in mine eye, The goodliest woman that ever wore fore part of Satin: To see what these female creatures are, when they deal with two or three Nations; how quickly they were carbuncles and rich stones? now she is more ugly than a bawd.

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: She looked so then; fairness itself doth cloth her
In men's eyes, till they see me, and then they loath her.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.p: Loose no more minutes, come, let us follow them.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: With hue and cry, now I know her: this villainous drab is bawd, now I remember, to the Whore of Babylon; and we will never leave her, till she be carted: her face is full of those red pimples with drinking Aqua-vita, the common drink of all bawds: come.

div1.stage: Titania, Elfiron, Florimel, a gentleman standing aloof, and Ropus

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: What comes this paper for?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Your hand.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: The cause?

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: The Moon that from your beams did borrow light,
Hath from her silver bow shot pitchy clouds
To ecclipse your brightness: heaven took your part,
And her surprised; A jury of bright stars,
Have her unworthy found to shine again:
Your Fairies therefore on their knees entreat,
She may be pulled out from the firmament,
Where she was placed to glitter.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Must we then,
Strike those whom we have loved? albeit the children,
Whom we have nourished at our princely breast,
Set daggers to it, we could be content
To chide, not beat them, (might we use our will,)
Our hand was made to save, but not to kill.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You must not (cause he is noble) spare his blood.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: We should not, for he is noble that is good.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The fall of one, like multitudes on ye,
Makes all the rest, (of footing) be more nice:
But if by venturing on that glassy floor
Too far, he sinks, and yet rise with no more harm,
Ten thousand to like danger it doth arm:
All mercy in a Prince, makes vile the state,
All justice makes even cowards desperate.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: In neither of these seas, spread we our sails,
But are the impartial beam between both scales;
Yet if we needs must bow, we would incline
To that where mercy lies, that scale is divine:
But so to save were our own breast to wound,
Nay (which is more) our peoples: for their good,
We must the Surgeon play, and let out blood.
Every Peers birth sticks a new star in heaven,
But falling by Luciferan insolence,
With him a Constellation drops from thence.
Give me his Axe -- how soon the blow is given? writes
Witness: so little we in blood delight,
That doing this work, we wish we could not write.
Let us walk my Lords. Florimel?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Titan.
sp.l: Stay:
Not one armed man amongst us? you might now
Be all old-beaten soldiers: truth I thank ye;
If I were now a jewel worth the stealing,
Two thieves might bind you all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: With much ado.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Aye marry I commend yon gentleman.
Pray Sir come near, look you he is well provided
For all rough weathers: Sir, you may be proud,
That you can give arms better than these Lords,
I thank you yet, that if a storm should fall,
We could make you our shelter. A good sword?
This would go through stitch; had I heart to kill
I would wish no better weapon; but our days
Of quarrelling are past; Shall we put up Sir,
We have put up wrongs ere now, but this is right,
Nay we are not falling yet.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: It did us good
To see how your Majestic presence daunted
The silly gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: The silly gentleman!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He knew not how to stand, nor what to speak,

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: The silly gentleman? know you him Lords?
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Gotten hence poor wretch with shame.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: That wretch hath sworn to kill me with that sword,

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The traitor.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Lock the Court gates.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Guard her person.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: You guard it well. Alack! when lovers woo,
An extreme joy and fear, them so appall,
That over much love, shows no love at all.
Zeal sometimes over-does her part -- It is right --
When the fray is done, Cowards cry where is the Fight.
Florimell

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: The wolf is in his own snare: O damned slave!
I had like to have made his heart my poniards grave.
How got you to this knowledge? -- blessed heaven!

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: It came unto me strangely: from a window,
Mine eyes took mark of him; that he would shoot
It was told me, and I tried if he durst do it.
Is Ropus here, our Doctor?

sp.speaker: Rop.
sp.l: Gracious Lady.
You have a lucky hand since you were ours,
It quickens our taste well; fill us of that
You last did minister: a draught, no more,
And give it fire, even Doctor how thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Rop:
sp.l: I made a new extraction, you shall never
Relish the like.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Why, shall that be my last?

sp.speaker: Ro:
sp.l: O my dear Mistress!

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Go, go, I dare swear thou lovest my very heart.

sp.speaker: Parth:
sp.l: This scaly Serpent
Is thrown (as he deserves) upon the Sword
Of Justice; and to make these tidings twins,
I bring this happy news, Campeius,
(A Snake that in my bosom once I warmed:)
The man for whom -- .

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: O, we remember him.

sp.speaker: Parth:
sp.l: This Owl, that did not love your sacred light,
Stole over the Seas by darkness, and was held
In Babylon a bird of noble flight:
They turned him to a Goshawk, feathered him
Armed him with talents, and then gave him bells,
And hither charged him fly, he did: and soared
Over all your goodliest woods, and thickest groves,
Enticing birds that had the skill in song,
To learn harsh notes: and those that failed in voice,
He taught to peck the tender blossoms off,
To spoil the leafy trees, and with sharpe bills
To mangle all the Golden ears of corn.
But now he is taken.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Good shepherds ought not care,
How many foxes fall into the Snare.

sp.speaker: Elf:
sp.l: Your civil Doctor, Doctor Paridon
Casts Anchor on your shores again, being freighted
With a good venture, which he says, yourself
Must only have the sight of.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Bring him hither:
Lord Florimell, pray call Fideli to us

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Sure it is too hot.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: O rogue!

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Set it to cool.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Hell and damnation, Devils,

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: The damnedest treason! Dog: you whoreson dog;
O blessed maid: let not the toad come near her:
What is this? If it be his brewing, touch it not --
For it is a drench to kill the strongest Devil,
that is Drunk all day with brimstone: come suck, Weasel,
Suck your own teat, you -- pray;
Thou art preserved.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: From what? From whom?

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: Look to that Glister-pipe:
One crown does serve thy turn, but here is a thief,
That must have fifty thousand crowns to steal
Thy life: Here it is in black and white -- thy life,
Sirrah thou Urinal, Tynoco, Gama,
Andrada, and Ibarra, names of Devils,
Or names to fetch up Devils: thou knowest these Scarecrows.

sp.speaker: Rop:
sp.l: O Me! O mercy, mercy! I confess.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: Well said, thou shalt be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Have we for this
Heaped favours on thee.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: Heap halters on him: call the Guard: out polecat:
He smells, thy conscience stinks Doctor go purge
Thy soul, for it is diseased. Away with Ropus.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away with him: foh.

sp.speaker: Rop:
sp.l: Hear my tale but out.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: There is too much out already.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: On me accursed! and most miserable.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Goodness of virtue! is my blood so sweet,
That they would pay so dear for it

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: To suck Lambs,
What would not Wolves do, he that this paper wrote,
Had never meaning we should finger it.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Our mercy makes them cruel, hunt out these Leopards:
Their own spots will betray them: they build caves
Even in our parks: to them, him; and the rest,
Let death be sent, but sent in such a shape,
As may not be too frightful. Alack! what glory
Is it to buffet wretches bound in gives?
The debt is dearly paid that is paid with lives
O! leave us all.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: More Doctors! if this do
As well as the other best to hang him too.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Florimell! Stay,
But give us liberty.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: This is the blessed day for which (through want
Of those bright rays that sparkle from your eyes)
My frozen soul hath languished Goddess complete,
If you, a wretch so mean, will bid to speak,
I shall unclasp a book whose very first line,
(Being not well pointed) is my doom to death:
But if your sacred judgment (on the Margin,)
Control all wresting comments, All your subjects
Will fold me in their bosoms.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Give your mind.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: A Pilgrim have I been on foreign shores,
(Your gracious hand allowed it) in my wandering,
With Monsters I encountered of strange shape,
Some that sucked poison up, and spat it forth,
Upon your land some, that shot forked stings,
At your most God-like person: all were Giants,
Fighting against the heaven of your blessed reign:
With these ( O pardon me!) with these I held
A politic league, the lines of all their treasons,
(Drawn from one damned circle) met in me,
My heart became the Centre, and the point
Was this -- I dare not tell it.

sp.speaker: Peri:
sp.l: To kill you.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: How durst you (being our subject) wade so far?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: Your ear of mercy. I became a sponge
To drink up all their mischief, and lay drowned
In their infected waters, (with much loathing,)
Only that I before you might wring out
This their corruption, and myself make clear.
And now (immortal maid) I am not unlike
A casket wherein papers stuffed with danger,
Have close been locked, but those taken out, the chest
Serves to good use, so may my loyal breast:
For from their flinty hearts what sparks I got,
Were but to fire themselves.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: I praise your plot,
You make us now your debtor, but a day
Will come, when we shall pay. My Lord, we want your Arm.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: Um! I fear --

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Doctor, we will have (Sir) other Dialogues.

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: O shallow fool, thou hast thyself undone,
She is hardened and thou melted at one sun.

div1.stage: Enter Como, and the three Kings:

sp.speaker: Como.
sp.l: Our eyes have lusted for you, and your presence
Comes as the light to day, showers to the spring,
Or health to sick men.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Thanks most reverend Fathers.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Our blood ran all to water, yea our souls
Strove all (at once) to expire, (when it was blown
Hither from Fairy land, that all the darts
Which ours here, and your arm delivered there,
Fell either short, or lighted upon ye)
Lest you had lost blood in the enterprise.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: No, I wear stronger Armour: gamester-like
I saw the dogs brought forth; and set them on,
Till the Devil parted them; but plucked off none,
I kept aloof out of the reach of paws:
Better to fight with Lions than with laws.
What drums are these?

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Music of heaven.

sp.speaker: Como.
sp.l: The dancers revel in steel.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: These march to fill our Fleet.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: From whence we will march with proud victorious feet,
And walk on Fairies hearts, their beaten ways
With their own heads we will pave, whilst ours with bays,
And oak (the conquering soldiers wreath) we crown:
These hooks, or none, must pull their Cities down,
Invasion is the fire: See, See, in the Air
Angels hang beckoning us to make more haste,
Vengeance deferred grows weak, and runs to waste.
What is this? --

div1.stage: Enter a Herrald before one: sounds once, and stays.

sp.speaker: Como.
sp.l: Ere we take ship, we must to Court.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: In thunder: it is the soldiers sport.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: It is the Imperial pleasure, decree, peremptory edict, and dreadful command ( upon pain of a curse to be denounced upon him that is disobedient) from her who hath power given her to make the backs of stubborn Kings her foot-stools, and Emperors her vassals: the mother of Nations; the triple-crowned head of the world; the purple-rider of the glorious beast; the most high, most supreme, and most adored Empress of Babylon; that no Captain Generals of Armies, Generals of Squadrons, Admirals, Colonels, Captains, or any other Officers of her magnificent, incomparable, formidable, and invincible Armada, which is ordained to swallow up the kingdom of Fairy, shall presume to set one foot on shipboard, till her sacred hand hath blessed the enterprise by sealing them all on the forehead, and by bowing their knees before the Beast. Sound, go on.

div1.stage: Dumb show: Empress on the Beast.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Feels the base earth our weight? is it common Air
We suck in and respire? do servile clouds,
(Whose azure wings spread over graves and tombs)
Our glorious body circumvolve? dare night
Cast her black nets into days crystal streams,
To draw up darkness on our golden beams:
And us to eclipse, why is not Babylon
In a contorted chair made all of stars,
Wound up by wheels as high, nay above the thrones
Supernal, which with Ioues own seat stand even,
That we might ride here as the Queen of heaven.
And with a spurn from our controlling foot,
That should like thunder shake the etherial floor,
Of life and heaven them both at once bereave,
That thither up dare clime without our leave.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: You do: you ride there now this is your Sphere,
Earth is all one with heaven when you are here.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Yet there is a hell on earth or if not hell,
Devils there are or worse than Devils, that roar only at you.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: At us? what, dare they roar?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Your pardon, and I will tell it.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Tell: We fear, no spots, the orb we shine in is so clear.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Thus then: the Fairy Adders hiss: they call you
The superstitious Harlot: purple where:
The whore that rides on the rose-coloured beast:
The great whore, that on many waters sitteth,
Which they call many Nations: whilst their Kings,
Are slaves to sate your lust, and that their blood,
(When with them you have done) serves as a flood,
For you to drink or swim in.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O profane!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Go on: the searching small wounds is no pain.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: These cowards thus when your back is turned (that strike)
Follow their blow and swear, that where you claim,
Supremacy monarchal over Kings,
It is but your tyrannous pride, and not your due.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: But what yourselves give, what have we from you?
You say we are your mother, and if so,
Must not sons kneel? they pay but what they owe.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: They say the robes of purple which you wear,
Your scarlet veils, and mantles are not given you
As types of honour and regality,
But dyed so deep with blood upon them spilt,
And that (all over you are ) with red murder gilt:
The drink even in that golden cup, they swear
Is wine sophisticated, that does run
Low on the lees of error, which in taste,
Is sweet and like the neat and wholesome juice
Of the true grape, but it is rank poison down.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Have we not all it tasted?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Nay, utter all.
Out of their lips you see flows nought but gall.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: What can my breath do more, to blast your cheeks,
And leave them glowing as red gads of steel?
My tongue is already blistered sounding this,
Yet must I whisper to your sacred ear:
That on your brow (they say) is writ a name
In letters mystical, which they interpret
Confusion, by great Babylon they mean
The City of Confusion.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: View our forehead?
Where are we printed with such Characters?
Point out these marks: which of you all can lay
A finger on that Mole that marks our face?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: They say you can throw mists before our eyes,
To make us think you fair.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Damned blasphemies.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: You shall with rods of iron scourge these treasons.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: The Mace is in your hand, grind them to dust.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: And let your blows be sound.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: For they are just.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Let us hear with what loud throats our thunder speaks,
Repeat our vengeance over, which to beat Kings
Must now fly over the seas with linen wings.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Our Galleons, Galleasses, Zabraes, Galleys,
Ships, Pynaces, Pataches, huge Caruiles,
For number, rib and belly are so great,
That should they want a Sea near Fairy land
Of depth to bear them up, they in their wombs
Might swim with a sea thither: here are briefs
Of your imperial Armies.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Read them loud:
Thunder never speaks, but the voice cracks a cloud.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: In the first Squadron twelve great Galleons:
Float like twelve moving Castles: Zabraes two.
Habilimented gloriously for war,
With Soldiers, Seamen, shot, and ordinance:
This Squadron stout Medyna does command:
Who of the maine is Captain General.
The second Squadron brave Ricalde leads,
Being Admiral to fourteen Galleons.
Flores de Ualdes guides the third, the fourth
Follows the silken streamers of the haughty
Pedro de Valdes that tried warrior.
Oquendo in the fifth front cries a Charge.
Bretandona brings up the Leuantines
With his sixth Squadron: Gomes de Medyna
Wafts up the seventh like the God of war,
The eighth obeys Mendoza: and the ninth
Fierce Vgo de Montada: all these Squadrons,
For vessel, numbered are one hundred thirty,
The sight of Soldiers, Mariners, and Slaves
Twenty nine thousand, eight hundred thirty three.
Pieces of brass for battery these,
Six hundred thirty: add to these Galleons
Twenty Caruiles, and Saluees ten: which make
The whole Armada, eightscore lusty sail.
Add to all these your Generals of Armies,
Your Captains, Ensign bearers, (which in role,
Are eightscore and eleven) the Voluntaries,
With officers and servants, then the Regiments
That are in pay: to these, all men of orders,
All ministers of justice: and to these
Supplies of forces that must second us,
And last that host of stars which from the Moon
Will fall to guide us on: these totalled up,
You shall a hundred thousand swords behold
Brandished at once, whose -- stands
Men will seem born with weapons in their hands.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Go: cut the salt some with your mooned keels,
And let our Galleons feele even child-birth pangs,
Till their great bellies be delivered
On the soft Fairy shores: captive their Queen,
That we may thus take off her crown, whilst she
Kneels to these glorious wonders, or be trampled
To death for her contempt: burn, batter, kill,
Blow up, pull down, ruin all, let not white hairs,
Nor red cheeks blunt your wrath, snatch babes from breasts,
And when they cry for milk, let them suck blood,
Turn all their fields to lakes of jellied gore,
That Sea-men one day sailing by the land
May say, there Fairy kingdom once did stand.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: They shall.

sp.speaker: 3. King:
sp.l: It is done already.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.l: To be sure
You all are ours, bow and adore the beast;
On whom we ride.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We fall beneath his feet.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.l: Be blessed, obedience is in sons most sweet,
O strange, to you he stoops as you before him,
Humility, he bows whilst you adore him:
To kindle lusty fires in all your blood,
A health to all, and as our cup goes round,
Draw near, we will mark you for our chosen flock,
Who builds on hearts confirmed, builds on a rock:
The seal of heaven! who on their foreheads wear it,
We choose for counsel: on their hands who bear it,
We mark for Action: Here, a health to all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Brave health! to pledge it, see Kings prostrate fall.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.l: On:

sp.speaker: All:
sp.l: On:

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Sing war thy loud and loftiest notes.
We win; our ships meet none but fisher-boats.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: What if I show you a foundation,
Firm as earths fixed Centre? a strong warrant,
To strike the head off, an Injunction
That bids me do it: A dispensation
For what I do: A pardon signed, that gives
Indulgence plenary, and full remission
(For any criminal breach of the highest Law)
After it is done: nay more, a voice as clear
As that of Angels, which proclaims the act,
Good, honourable, meritorious,
Lawful, and pious, what if I show you this?

sp.speaker: Cox:
sp.l: Come, come, you cannot, then let riotous heirs
Beg patents to kill fathers: grant but this
Murder may be a fair Monopoly,
And Princes stabbed by Act, of parliament:
Who is it dare that thing meritorious call,
Which fiends themselves count diabolical?

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Your coldness makes me wonder: why should you
Run up to the neck, from drowning to save her,
That treads upon your head; your throat, to sink you?

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: Say you should wound me; should I (in revenge)
Murder myself? for what can be the close
But death, dishonour; yea, damnation
To an act so base, nay so impossible.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Impossible; the parting of the air,
Is not more easy: look upon the Court,
Through narrow sights, and she is the fairest mark,
And soonest hit of any: like the Turke
She walks not with a Ianisarie -- Guard,
Nor (as the Russia with foul-big-boned slaves,
Strutting on each side with the slicing Axe,
Like to a pair of hangmen: no, alas:
Her Courts of Guard are Ladies, and sometimes)
She is in the garden with as small a train,
As is the Sun in heaven: and our Access,
May then as easy be as that of Clients,
To Lawyers out of term -- time.

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: Grant all this:
Nay, say the blow were given: how would you scape?

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: O, sir by water. --

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: Aye but. --

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Nay, good cozen. --

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: You leap as short as safety, as at stars:
By water: why the gates will all be locked,
Waiters you must have none.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Hear me,
You must not have a man, and if you kill
With powder, air betrays you.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Powder! no sir, my dag shall be my dagger
Good sweet Cozen mark but how smooth
My paths are: look you sir,

sp.speaker: Cox:
sp.l: I have thought upon a course.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Nay, nay, hear mine,
You are my mark, suppose you are my mark,
My level is thus low, but ere I rise,
My hand has got up thus hie: the dear being struck,
The heard that stand about so frighted are,
I shall have leave to scape, as does a pirate,
Who having made a shot through one more strong,
All in that ship run to make good the breach,
Whilst the other sails away. How like you this?

sp.speaker: Cox:
sp.l: As I like paper harness.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Ha, well, pause then:
This bow shall stand unbent, and not an arrow
Be shot at her until we take our aim
In S. Iagoes park; a rare, rare Altar!
The fittest to sacrifise her blood upon:
It shall be there: in S. Iagoes park:
Ha coz! it shall be there: in the mean time,
We may keep followers (nine or ten a piece)
Without suspicion: numbers may work wonders;
The storm being sudden too: for were the guard
A hundred strong about her, look you sir,
All of us well appointed -- Case of dags
To each man, see you? you shoot there, we here,
Unless some spirits put the bullets by,
There is no escape for her: say the dags fail,
Then to our swords. -- Come, there is no mettle in you.

sp.speaker: Cox:
sp.l: No mettle in me? would your wars were honest;
I quickly would find Armour: what is the goad
So sharpe, that makes you wildly thus to run
Upon your certain ruin?

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Goad? sharp poniards,
Why should I spare her blood?

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: She gave you yours.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: To have taken it had been tyranny, her own lips
Confessed I struck her laws not hard: I have spent
My youth, and means in serving her: what reap I?
Wounds (discontents) what gives she me? good words
(Sweet meats that rot the eater:) why, last day
I did but beg of her the mastership
Of Santa Cataryna, it was denied me.

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: She keeps you to a better.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Aye tush, that is not all:
My bonds are yonder sealed; And she must must fall.

sp.speaker: Coz:
sp.l: Well coz, I will hence.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: When shall I see you?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Ha.
Soon: very soon: sooner than you expect,
Let me but breath, and what I mean to do,
I shall resolve you.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Fare you well,

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Adieu. --

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: News; thundering news sweet Lady: Envy, Ambition,
Theft sacreligious, and base treason, lay
Their heads and hands together, at one pull
To heave you from your throne: that mannish woman-Devil,
That lustful bloody Queen of Babylon,
Hath (as we gather ripe intelligence)
Rigged an Armed fleet, which even now beats the waves,
Beasting to make their wombs our Cities graves.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Let it come on: our General leads above them,
Earth-quakes may kingdoms move, but not remove them.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He yonder, he that plays the fiend at sea,
The little Captain that is made all of fire,
Swears (Flemming-like) by twenty thousand Devils,
If our tongues walk thus, and our feet stand still,
So many huge ships near our coasts are come,
An Oyster boat of ours will scarce find room.
He swears the winds have got the sails with child,
With such big bellies, all the linen is gone,
To find them linen and in Babylon,
That there is not one rag left,

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Why swells this fleet?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Thus they give out, that you sent forth a Drake,
which from their rivets beat their water-fowl,
Tore silver feathers from their fairest Swans,
And plucked the Halcyon's wings that rove at sea,
And made their wild-ducks under-water dive,
So long, that some never came up alive.
This Sea-pie Babylon, her bugbear calls,
For when her bastards cry, let the nurse cry
But this, the Drake comes, they hush presently,
For him they will cudgel us: will you have the troth?
That scarlet-whore is thirsty and no blood,
But yours, and ours (sweet maid) can do her good.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: That drake shall out again: to counsel Lords.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Come, come, short counsel: better get long swords,

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Good Lady dread not you, what ere befall.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: We will die first, yours is the last funeral: away, away, away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Posts, posts, call messengers, posts with all speed.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: How? fear? why should white bosoms.
Fear a Tyrants Arm?
Tyrants may kill us, but not do us harm.
Are we your prisoners that you guard us thus?
Stay, And you too, we are alone: when last
We entertained your speech (as we remember)
Close trains and dangerous you did discover
To fire which you were prayed.

sp.speaker: Pari,
sp.l: I was.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: And yielded.
Albeit it were against our life.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: Most true. -- my reasons. --

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: We forget them not: at that time
Here was but one, (true) but one councillor,
Who stood aloof, heard nothing; and though a blood
Of courser veins than ours, would have been stirred
Into a sea tempestuous to boyle up,
And drown the Pilot that durst sail so far,
Yet of our princely grace ( though it was not fit,
Nor stood with wisdom) did we silence it.
These heaped favours, not withstanding (Doctor)
It is in our ear: the hammers lie not still,
But that new clubs of iron are forging now,
To bruise our bones, and that yourself do know,
The very Anvil where they work.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Hear us, because it is thought some of those worser spirits,
And most malignant that at midnight rise
To blast our Fairy circles by the Moon,
Are your Familiars.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Sir anon.
Thee therefore I conjure (if not by faith,
Oathed allegiance, nor thy conscience,
Perhaps this rankling ulcerateth them)
Yet by thy hopes of bliss, tell, and tell true,
Who is it must let us blood?

sp.speaker: Pary.
sp.l: O unhappy man;
That thou shouldst breathe thus long: mirror of women,
I open now my breast even to the heart,
My very soul pants on my lips: none, none,
I know of none.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Well; none: rise and take heed,
They are no common drops when Princes bleed.
What hour is this? does not my alarm strike?
This watch goes false.

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: This watch goes true.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: All is nought. -- what hour is this?

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: Thy last hour, O heavens, further
The work you have begun: where art thou heart?

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: O we see it: Doctor wind up the wheel, it is down,

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: How now? what struck thee down? thy looks are wild:
Why was thine armed hand reared to his height?
What black work art thou doing?

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: Of damnation upon myself.

sp.speaker: Tita:
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Pari:
sp.l: Your words have split my heart in thousand shivers,
here, here that sticks which I fear will not out
Better to die than live suspected. Had not your bright eyes
Turned back upon me, I had long ere this
Lain at your feet a bloody sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Stained Altars please not us: why dost thou weep?
Thou makest my good thoughts of thee now decline,
Who loves not his own blood, will never spare mine,
Why dost thou weep?

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: When on your face I look,
Methinks I see those Vertues drawn alive
Which did in Elfilyne the seventh survive,
(Your fathers father, and your grandfather,)
And then that you should take me for a serpent
Gnawing the branches of that glorious tree,
The grief melts even my soul, O pardon me.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Contract thy spirits together, be composed;
Take a full man into thee, for behold
All these black clouds we clear: look up, it is day,
The sun shines on thee still: we willH1; read: away --

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: O matchless; I am all poison, and yet she
Turns all to goodness by wise tempering me.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: If thou provest copper -- well; this makes us strong
As towers of flint. All traitors are but waves,
That beat at rocks, their own blows dig their graves.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: For not doing am I damned: how are my spirits
Haled, tortured, and grown wild? on leaves eternal
Vows have I writ so deep, so bound them up,
So texted them in characters capital,
I cannot race them but I blot my name
Out of the book of sense: mine oath stands filled
On your court-roles. Then keep it, up to heaven
Thy ladder is but thus hie: courage, to kill
Ten men I should not freeze thus: yet her murder
Cannot be named bloodshed, for her Fairies
Are all of faith, and fealty assoiled,
The balm that her anointed is washed off,
Her crown is now not hers; upon the pain
Of a black curse, no more must I obey her,
I climb to heaven by this, climb then and slay her.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: A tyrants strange, but just end! -- --
Ran mad for sleep, and died Princes that plunge
Their souls in rank and godless appetites
Must seek no rest but in the arms of Sprites.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Nothing to read? that (if my nerves should shrink
And make mine arm revolt) I might have colour
To usurp this walk of hers: what is this? see, see
An Angel thrusts this iron into my hand,
My warrant signed from Babylon to kill her,
Endorsed, the last will of Paridell. --
Le concede sua Benedictione, pleuaria indulgenza,
Eo remissione disuttils peccati -- tuttili peccati --
All, all my sins are paid off, paying this,
It is done, it is done, All you blessed powers I charm,
Now, now, knit all your sinews to this arm.

div1.stage: As he offers to step to her, he stays suddenly, vpon the approach of Fidely, Florimel, Parthenophil, Elfiron, the Ladies, a Guard, and the Doctors Cozen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: You have proved yourself a loyal gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The hand of Angels guide us: She is not here,
The Queen is killed; treason: Wenches, raise the Court.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Walk several ways first.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ways; she is murdered: treason.

sp.speaker: Tyt.
sp.l: Treason; a sword. What traitor dare? who? where?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A guard: the damned serpent, see, lurks here.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Sure here is some nest they breed in: paw him fast,
This Wolf, this Toad (mark, he swells red with poison,)
This learned knave is sworn to murder thee.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: I defy any man that speaks it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ha: -- defy this noble, honest gentleman,
Defy him, he shall spit it on thy face,
Thy beard scald Doctor.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: And dost thou betray me! Sayst thou so?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: And will seal my speech with blood.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: My no against his yea; My no is an good.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Better, his yeas go naked, and your noes
Very well cloaked: off, come, truth naked goes,
And here is his naked truth. --

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: O me; -- now nothing but your mercy me can save.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: It must not: Princes that would safely live,
May grieve at traitors falls but not forgive.
Let him be summoned to the bar of shame.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: It is welcome, a black life, ends in black fame.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Now to the business,
We have one foot.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Aye, aye, look to the head.
The hangman cures those members.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: What is done?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: This (sacred Lady:) we with either hand
Have raised an Army both by sea and land.
Your goodly ships bear the most royal freight,
That the world owes (true hearts:) their wombs are full,
Of noble spirits, each man in his face
Shows a Kings dancing look, the soldiers stand
So thickly on the deck, so bravely plumed,
(The Silken steamers waving over their heads)
That (seeing them) you would judge it were Pentecost,
And that the jolly youngsters of your towns,
Had flocked together in gay multitudes,
For May-games, and for summer merriment's,
They look so cheerily: in such little room
So many Fairies never dwelt at once,
Never so many men were born so soon,
The drum that gave the call, could not be heard
For jostling armours: ere the call was done,
It was so ringed about with groves of pikes,
That when they brake on both sides to give way,
The beating of the drum was thunder noise,
Whilst coats of steel clashed so on coats of steel,
Helmets on helmets that they struck out fire,
Which showed like lightning, or those flames that fly
From the huge Cyclops-hammer, when they sweat
To forge Ioues thunder: And in such a heat
With quickness rush they armed forth, captains swore,
Harness was sure the clothes they daily wore.
Men faster came to fight then to a feast.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay, women sued to us they might be pressed.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Old grandams that on crutches bear up age,
Full nimbly buckled Armours on their sons,
And when it was on, she clapped him on his back,
And spake thus, run my boy, fight till thou art dead,
Thy blood can never be more bravely shed.

sp.speaker: Tita:
sp.l: How are the numbers you have levied?

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: What your sea-forces are, this brief doth speak.

sp.speaker: Elf.
sp.l: We have raised double walls to fence your land.
The one the body of a standing Camp,
Whose tents by this are pitched in Beria,
On the shores point, to bar the foe from footing.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: over that Camp at Beria we create
Your Florimell Lieutenant General;

sp.speaker: Elf:
sp.l: The other is to guard your royal person.

sp.speaker: Tita:
sp.l: Whose charge is yours: the sea Fideli, yours.

sp.speaker: Elf:
sp.l: The standing camp of horsemen and of foore,
These numbers fill. Lances two hundred fifty three. Horsemen seven hundred sixty nine.
Footmen twenty two thousand. The moving Army, which attends on you,
Is thus made up: of horsemen and of foot, Lancers four hundred eighty one.
Light horse-men one thousand four hundred twenty one. Footmen Thirty four thousand fifty.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: We do not raise our hopes on points of spears.
A handful is an host, in a good fight,
Lambs may beat Lions in a war not right.
The General of all armies be our leader,
Be full of courage Lords as ye are in years,
For this be sure we will not outlive our peers.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: We will all live, but will first have them by the ears.

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Go on, your conduct be the prosperous hand,
Make you the sea good, we will not loose the land.
Your Queen will to the field, It shall be said,
Once soldiers to their Captain had a Maid.

div1.stage: Truth and Plain-dealing leading soldiers with drum and colours, Time meeting them.

sp.speaker: Time:
sp.l: You sweat well in this harvest.

sp.speaker: Plai:
sp.l: Nay, when we come to bind up the whore of Babylon's
Punks and Pynaces in sheaves, we will sweat worse.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.l: Have you bestowed the other bands?

sp.speaker: Tru:
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.l: Incorporate this to you then: it is the mandate
Of your Lieutenant General, You fight
In your great Fairies quarrel, and Truths right,
Stand therefore to it.

sp.speaker: Uolu:
sp.l: I will have no wounds on my shoulders, I scorn to run,
Or to cry out of warlike kibes in the heel.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.l: Go (thou most God-like maid) and buckle on
The breast-plates fetched from thine own Armoury,
Let every soldier wear one, on each leader
Bestow a guiding-staff, and a strong shield
That may as faithful be to his good sword
As thou art to his heart: head all the spears
With gold of Angel-proof. Sit like a dove
upon the Horseman's helm, and on his face
Fan with thy silver wings sweet victory,
Go, beat thy drum, that men may know thy march,
Spread thine own colours (Truth) so let them shine,
Soldiers may swear they will follow none but thine. Away.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I fly, swift as the winged wings.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Today is workaday with me for all I have my best clothes on, what do you set me to?

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.p: Go thou and sweep the abuses from the camp.

sp.speaker: Plai.
sp.p: Conscience has left no brooms big enough to do that clean,

sp.speaker: Time:
sp.p: Then purge the tents of all infectious aires.

sp.speaker: Plai.
sp.p: Yonder is one infection new broke out, if it be not stopped From running, will choake us all.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.p: Name it, I will minister the remedy.

sp.speaker: Plai.
sp.p: Time may do it, this it is: A Broker and his wife that dropped out of the Hangman's budget but last day; are now eating into the Camp, and are victualers to it: their very Cannes have hoops of gold lace now, that banged Captains Jerkins all over but yesterday: fifteen Lieutenants have eaten up their buff Jerkins with cheese and mustard: Nay this villain of fourscore in the hundred has set up three Armourers shops with harness caps, and pewter coats, that are lined clean out with Ale: the Rogue lies every night upon as many feathers which grew in soldiers hats, as will undo four hundred School masters to hire them for their boys to go afeasting.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.p: Breed such disorders amongst the soldiers?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: They swarm like lice: nay his wife tickles it too, for three Musketeers came but to drink Tobacco in her cabin, and she fired their flasks and tuch-boxes.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.p: Go rid the Camp of these, and all like these.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: If any soldier swear I will cashier him too.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.p: You will scarce leave two in the Army then.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: What shall I do with those Pioneers yonder?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: You know the ground, lead them to cast up trenches. Away.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: They are by this time leading one another, for when I left them, I left them all casting, I will now go see what it comes to.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.l: I will fly hence to the fleet of Babylon,
And from their tacklings and their maine-mast tops.
Time shall shoot vengeance through his bow of steel,
Wedge like to split their Navy to the keel.
I will cut their Princes down as blades of grass,
As this glass, so the Babylonian power,
The higher shall run out to fill the lower.

sp.speaker: 3. Ki.
sp.l: The sulphurous Aetna belcheth on our ships,
Cut Cables, or the whole fleet downs in fire.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Holla.

sp.speaker: 2 Ki.
sp.l: Of Babylon.

sp.speaker: 1. Ki.
sp.l: What Hulks are these, that are on fire?

sp.speaker: 3. Ki.
sp.l: The Devils: the sea is on fire, the Devil sure takes Tobacco.

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Where is Madyna?

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Close under hatches, dares not show his head.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Damnation of such livered Generals. Where is brave
Ricalde?

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Our Admiral the Admiral of our Navy; wise Ricalde.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Our stout and brave Ricalde keeps his bed.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: All poxes fire him out; Pedro de Valdes
Having about him fifty Canons throats,
Stretch wide to bark is boarded, taken.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Taken?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Without resistance: Pyementelly sunk,
Oquendo burnt, Monca la drowned or slain,

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: The ship of all our medicaments is lost.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Dogs eat our medicaments, such are our wounds
We more shall Sextons need than Surgeons.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: What course is best?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: The best to get the day:
Is to hoist sails up, and away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away, away, hoist sails up and away.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: A world of men and wealth lost in one day.

div1.stage: Florimell followed by Captains, Mariners and Gunners with Linstockes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Shoot, shoot, they answer; brave: more Linstocks: shoot:
This stratagem dropped down from heaven in fire.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Board, board, hoist more sails up, they fly, shoot, Shoot.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: We never held a royal Court till now:
(Warriors) would it not seem most glorious,
To have Ambassadors to greet us thus?
Our chair of state, a drum: for sumptuous robes
Ruffling about us, heads cased up in globes.
Of bright reflecting steel: for revellers
(Treading soft measures) marching soldiers,
Trust me, I like the martial life so well,
I could change Courts to camper, in sultles to dwell.
It is a brave life: Methinks it best becomes
A Prince to march thus, between guns and drums.
My fellow soldiers I dare swear you will fight,
To the last man, your Captain being in fight.

sp.speaker: Uolu:
sp.l: To the last least man's little finger.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What flames through all your blood your breath inspires.

sp.speaker: Tita:
sp.l: For that we come not: no breast here wants fires.
It was kindled in their cradles, strength, courage, zeal,
Meet in each bosom like a three-fold floe,
We come with yours to venture our own blood.
For you and we are fellows; thus appears it,
The soldier keeps the crown on, the prince wears it.
Of all men you we hold the most most dear,
But for a soldier I had not been here.

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: Do not their guns offend you?

sp.speaker: Tita:
sp.l: How? we are tried,
Why I am born a soldier by the fathers side.
The Cannon (thunders Zany) plays to us,
Soft musics tunes, and more melodious:
And me more rarely like, because all these,
That now can speak the language of stern war,
Could not speak swords, or guns, nay scarce could go,
Nay were not born, but like to new sown grain
Lay hid in the mold, when we went to be crowned,
Though now they are tall corn fields, covering the ground.

sp.speaker: Plai.
sp.p: Room, room, news, news, the youngest news that ever was brought forth amongst men at Arms: a woman (sweet mistress) is brought to bed of a man child in the Camp: a boy that looks as if he would shoot off already: the bed they have swaddled him in, is the piece of an old torn Ancient: his blankets are two soldiers Medallions: his cradle is the hollow back-piece of a rusty Armour: his head lies in a Murrain that is quilted to keep him warm, the first thing that ever he laid hold on, was a truncheon, on which a Captain leaned to look upon him, he will be a warrior I warrant. A Can of beer is set to his mouth already, yet I doubt he will prove but a victualler to the Camp: A notable fat double-chinned bulchin:

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: A child born in our Camp! go give him fame,
Let him be Beria called, by the Camps name.

sp.speaker: Plai.
sp.p: That is his name then: Beria, in steed of a Midwife, a Cantaino shall bear him to the Pount, and if there be any women to follow it, they shall either trail pikes, or shoot in Caliners; who would sweat thus to get gossips for another man's child? but fathers themselves are gulled so sometimes, farewell mistress.

sp.speaker: Tita:
sp.l: With roses us you crown, yourself with palm,

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Had we all wounds, your words are sovereign balm.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Are those clouds dispersed that strove to dim our light?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: And driven into the gloomy caves of night.

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: Our hands be heaved up for it.

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.l: There is good cause,
We are bound to do so by the higher laws.
Those roaring Whales came with devouring wombs
To swallow up your kingdoms: foolish heirs;
When half of them scarce knew where it did stand,
Under what Zenith, did they share your land.
At dice they played for Pasteries, at each cast
A Knight at least was lost: what do you set?
This Knight cries one (and names him) no, a Lord
Or none, it is done, he throws and sweeps the board,
His hat is full of Lords up to the brim,
The sea threw next at all, won all and him,
Would you these Gamesters see now?

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: See now? where?
They will scarce see us, the last sight cost so dear.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Bid you me do it, it is done, Time takes such pride,
To wait on you, he will lackey by your side.
Those days of their Arrival, battle, flight,
And ignominious shipwrecks (like lost Arrows)
Are out of reach: of them the world receives
But what Times book shows turning back the leaves,
But if you will see this Concubine of Kings,
In her majestic madness with her sons,
That hour is now but numbering out in sand,
These minutes are not yet run through Times hand,
For you and for your Fairies sweet delight
Time shall do this,

sp.speaker: Tyta:
sp.l: It will be a glorious sight,

sp.speaker: Time,
sp.l: Unseen you shall both see and hear these wonders.
On the green Mount of Truth: let the Army move,
And meet you in the vale of Oberon,
Your captives are sent thither: quick as thought
You shall fly hence upon my active wings,
Time at one instant sees all Courts of Kings.

div1.stage: Time descending: Enter the Empress, three Kings, and four Cardinals.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Hence: sting me not: you are Scorpions to my breast,
Diseases to my blood: he dies that speaks.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You are mad.

sp.speaker: Ambe.
sp.l: You are mad.

sp.speaker: 4. Card.
sp.l: o fails not heaven!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Be silent:
Be damned for your speech: as you are for Act,
You are all black and close conspirators
In our disgrace.

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You lie:

sp.speaker: 4. Card:
sp.l: O horrible?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You Rave yet know not why,

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Thou sayst all is lost.

sp.speaker: 3. King:
sp.l: Drowned, burnt, split upon rocks, cast over board,
Throats cut by Kerns, whose hairs like else-locks hang,

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: One of those shamrock-eaters at one break fast,
Slit fourscore we zand-pipes of ours,

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Of yours.
Oquendo burnt, Piementelli Slain,
Pedro de Valdes taken,

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Could dwarfs beat Giants?

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: In one day fell five hundred Galleons fifteen
Drowned at the same time; or which was worser taken,
The same day made a thousand prisoners.
Yet not a cherry stone of theirs was sunk.
Not a man slain nor taken, not drowned.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: O damned

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: Two with two spit-frog Rapiers took a Galleon,

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: O pity her.

sp.speaker: 3. K.
sp.l: Let her taste all.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Fall thunder.
And wedge me into earth, stiff as I am
So I may be but deaf, turn me into
A speckled Adder: O you Mountains fall,
And cover me, that of me, memory
May never more be found.

sp.speaker: 4. Card:
sp.l: O holy mother!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Earth, I will suck all thy venom to my breast,
It cannot hurt me so as do my sons,
My disobedient, desperate, dampened sons,
My heavy curse shall strike you.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Kneel down and beg a pardon, least her curse. --

sp.speaker: 1. King.
sp.l: Aye that is the block, we must kneel, or do worse,

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Lift up your sacred head: your children come,
Upon their knees to take a mothers doom.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: O Syrian Panthers! you spend breath most sweet,
But you are spotted over, from head to feet,
This neck I will yoke, -- this throat a stairs I will make,
By which I will climb -- like stubble thou shalt burn,
In my hot vengeance.

sp.speaker: 2. King.
sp.l: Vengeance I defy.
I shall fall from thee, since thou makest my breast
Thy scorn, true Kings such baseness will detest.
Electors will I call, and they shall make thee,
But servant of mine Empires they shall thrust
A ring into thy nostrils.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Come let me kiss thy cheek: I did but jest,

sp.speaker: Tyta.
sp.l: Mark: those that most adore her, most are slaved,
She never does grow base, but when she is braved:

sp.speaker: 3. King.
sp.l: You seem still angry.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No, yes, lead the way,
Never was day to me thus Tragical,
Great Babylon thus low did never fall.

sp.speaker: Tita.
sp.l: Thanks Time for this; launch forth to Oberons veil
We are near shore: your hands to strike our sail.
